Subject: [sfraves] (nrr) QOD (Mon)

Well, it's almost 11 AM on the east coast ...

Hopefully we'll see Chuck posting his Punx QOD more often than twice a =20
week.  Refine it!

I realized that Halloween is scary enough for me to want to stay home, =20
then do mop-up the next day.  Without getting dressed up or anything.  =20
I tried this new pub if you could call it that, it's called The Parish =20
over on the West Side, that I like, because it's a few blocks from me, =20
and I drank a beer that is 11.7% alcohol.  So basically like a syrupy, =20
fermented wine almost.  I drank that, and another beer that was about =20
8%, another about 6%, so by the time I got home and cracked a Modelo, =20
I literally passed out without drinking that Modelo.  Don't tell anyone!

I was going to take a break from posting the QOD for a while, to =20
finish working on my website, etc., but then I got to wondering what =20
George Soros has to say.  And I know you're curious too.  He's a rich =20
philanthropist who is also convicted of insider trading in France.  =20
Hmm.  So here you go.  Have fun with it.

Try to stay away from those Illuminati Freemasons that have =20
invisibility suits.

--

The absurdity of its illegality has been clear to me for some time. I =20
learned about pot from my kids and realized it was a lot better than =20
Scotch, and I loved the Scotch. Then I went to my doctor, and he said, =20
'I'm thrilled. You're drinking too much. You're much better off doing =20
pot than drinking.

So I know it's another Bad Religion lyric=2C but honestly=2C they're one of=
 the most politically relevant bands of the last few decades (IMHO)=2C and =
with tomorrow being doomsday=2C er=2C election day....this seemed appropria=
te.

"You Are (The Government)" by Bad Religion


Hey sit down and listen and they'll tell you when you're wrong.

Eradicate but vindicate as "progress" creeps along.

Puritan work ethic maintains its subconscious edge

As Old Glory maintains your consciousness.

There's a loser in the house=2C and a puppet on the stool=2C

And a crowded way of life=2C and a black reflecting pool=2C

And as the people bend=2C the moral fabric dies=2C

The country can't pretend to ignore its people's cries.

You are the government.

You are jurisprudence.

You are the volition.

You are jurisdiction.

And I make a difference too.

four score and 16 months ago the nation was faced with a choice.... or so we thought...

never
in my wildest dreams did i think that bush would win in 2000. oh,
wait.... he didn't. that's right, there was some wierdness in florida
and they couldn't count the votes and the supreme court declared the
election unconstitutional and....

never in my wildest dreams did
i think that bush would win in 2004. oh wait.... he didn't? we'll never
really know will we? rather than continue disputing the results in ohio
based on overt election fraud kerry conceded the election.

never in my wildest dreams did i think that bush would win the election in 2008. oh wait...

HE'S NOT RUNNING??????

what's
up with that? is it possible that some part of the constitution still
holds true in this country? is the nightmare over? someone other than
bush will be president of the united states?

i don't know about you, but i think that calls for a celebration.

join me on november 4th to celebrate the end of an error.



Tuesday November 4th
Mighty (119 Utah @ 15th)
9pm-2am
$5 (free before 11 w/ "I Voted" sticker)

we'll
have snacks and a television set up in the back room for the couch
potatoes... but if you find you can't tear yourself away from the sound
system we will be broadcasting the results throughout the club!

so go vote and then join me on the dancefloor as we celebrate the end of an error!

peace love and beats- pufuchu

four score and 16 months ago the nation was faced with a choice.... or so we thought...

never
in my wildest dreams did i think that bush would win in 2000. oh,
wait.... he didn't. that's right, there was some wierdness in florida
and they couldn't count the votes and the supreme court declared the
election unconstitutional and....

never in my wildest dreams did
i think that bush would win in 2004. oh wait.... he didn't? we'll never
really know will we? rather than continue disputing the results in ohio
based on overt election fraud kerry conceded the election.

never in my wildest dreams did i think that bush would win the election in 2008. oh wait...

HE'S NOT RUNNING??????

what's
up with that? is it possible that some part of the constitution still
holds true in this country? is the nightmare over? someone other than
bush will be president of the united states?

i don't know about you, but i think that calls for a celebration.

join me on november 4th to celebrate the end of an error.



Tuesday November 4th
Mighty (119 Utah @ 15th)
9pm-2am
$5 (free before 11 w/ "I Voted" sticker)

Main Room:

Ernie Trevino vs. Donna Matrix -tagteaming the DnB-
Aaron Jae vs. Redstickman -tagteaming the ghettotech-
Niles - bringin back the breaks-
Pym -live set w Laela on violin-

Outside on the chill bus w/ the Ambient Mafia:

Dr. Toast
Squelchy
Peek
Drop
The Captain

we'll
have snacks and a television set up in the back room for the couch
potatoes... but if you find you can't tear yourself away from the sound
system we will be broadcasting the results throughout the club!

so go vote and then join me on the dancefloor as we celebrate the end of an error!

peace love and beats- pufuchu

X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] (nrr) QOD (Thu)

Today is Election Day, and I'll be around all day to answer questions =20
with election coverage every hour.

Continuing the story about Obama's birth certificate, et. al., I =20
listened to Mike Rivero's show, who thinks that Obama is marginally =20
better than McCain, says he had a debate with Webster Tarpley today on =20
the Alex Jones show, where it sounds like it became a heated, =20
polarized exchange.  Rivero continues to claim that he has seen the =20
birth certificate, and has also seen the newspaper announcements in =20
Hawaii from the time he was born and claims the birth certificate =20
issue is a closed case.  And of course there is the McCain birth =20
certificate issue, which did not seem to get much coverage in the news.

Then after Rivero left Tarpley was reported by a caller to say that =20
Rivero was full of hate.  So it's interesting to see who supports who =20
and what their reasons are.  I just did the quick and dirty CNN =20
Electoral Map calculator, and based the states on current polls =20
according to CNN, past election history, and hunches, respectively.  =20
It's pretty clear from that data that Obama will win.

No matter who wins, however, the creeping of the finance oligarchs =20
remains.  Colin Powell and Joe Biden both refer to some incident or =20
challenge that will occur soon after the inauguration.  Powell was =20
even so specific as to name dates.  So as the elites scurry toward an =20
era of left cover, what do statements like this mean?  More war?

Does anyone really believe that either of these two candidates will =20
get the military out of Iraq?  And don't forget where they get all the =20
money for these outrageous wars.  The march toward more liberty and =20
less tyranny is likely a multi-generational event.  The march toward =20
turning the world into a global feudalist state was.

--

If this mischievous financial policy, which has its origin in North =20
America, shall become endurated down to a fixture, then that =20
Government will furnish its own money without cost. It will pay off =20
debts and be without debt. It will have all the money necessary to =20
carry on its commerce. It will become prosperous without precedent in =20
the history of the world. The brains, and wealth of all countries will =20
go to North America. That country must be destroyed or it will destroy =20
every monarchy on the globe.

- Hazard Circular - London Times 1865

Subject: [sfraves] BSP - FREE party @ Mighty - TONIGHT

End of An Error
Tuesday, November 4th, 2008
Located @ Mighty (119 Utah st.)
$5 (free b4 11pm w/"Proof that you Voted" (sticker or stub))
9pm - 2am


It's the elections again, & it's ABOUT TIME!!!!! I know the
majority of you San Franciscans are hoping that soon we'll be
living in an Obama-nation, but I really must say that the last
8 years have truly been an abomination. So it's time to
CELEBRATE! Bush is going out of office, there's no possible way
he can get re-elected regardless of what happens in Florida,
and this sad saga in American history is finally coming to a
close.

Come join us @ Mighty where we'll be broadcasting the election
coverage throughout the club with a soundtrack provided by a
bunch of amazing artists who just can't help but celebrate the
fact that there really is a light at the end of the tunnel, and
yes, it's changing colors.

In the back room we'll have some food & snacks as well as a
couple televisions setup in a more relaxing environment so that
the more serious voter can catch all the election info as it
comes in.

Outside, Peter (TeacherWiththeBus.com) will be bringing down
his awesome bus with the dance-floor & the Ambient Mafia will
be providing the music, visuals, & who knows what else.

Ambient Mafia DJs:
The Captain
Drop
Peek
Squelchy

w/Special Guest:
Dr. Toast (False Profit)


In the main room, music will be provided by a couple SF dj's
that I'm sure most of you know, as well as a couple that you
probably should know. We still may or may not have a special
guest show up to rock the decks, but I guess you'll just have
to come to find out.

Aaron Jae vs. Redstickman (E.B./Ambient Mafia)
Special Ghetto-tech set

Ernie Trevino vs. Donna Matrix (Space Cowboys/Newsbreakz)
Special DnB set

Niles (mk2 systems)
Pym w/ Laela on violin

Subject: [sfraves] Dance: The underground is alive and kicking

--Boundary_(ID_tQYI3yBPC5krVE071TdcIQ)
Content-type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII; format=flowed; delsp=yes
Content-transfer-encoding: 7BIT

Dance: The underground is alive and kicking

By Rupert Howe
Monday, 3 November 2008

During this year's Frieze Art Fair a panel chaired by the music writer  
Simon Reynolds asked the question: "Is The Underground Over?" The  
speakers, who included Cosey Fanni Tutti of Throbbing Gristle and  
pioneering acid house duo Chris & Cosey, weren't there to discuss  
electronic music specifically. Instead they focused on "a diverse  
array of music undergrounds including free folk, noise, extreme  
metal". But the debate is just as relevant to dance culture in the two  
decades since acid house first made headlines in the UK.

http://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/music/music-magazine/music-magazine-features/dance/dance-the-underground-is-alive-and-kicking-988594.html




Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

The US is:  "...a nation of 200 million used-car salesmen with all the  
money we need to buy guns and no qualms about killing anybody else in  
the world who tries to make us uncomfortable."
-Hunter S. Thompson

"Friend, hope for the truth while you are alive.  Jump into experience  
while you are alive!  What you call "salvation" belongs to the time  
before death.  If you don't break your ropes while you are alive, do  
you think ghosts will do it after?"
-Kabir



     *

--Boundary_(ID_tQYI3yBPC5krVE071TdcIQ)--

Happy Guy Fawkes Day Everybody.

Like Sublime's "April 26th, 1992"
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vGAs-i32t5c(which thankfully we did not
see a repeat of last night), where Bradley
Nowell completely got the date wrong, it was on the 29th of April, 1992 that
America burned, but they like the take so they kept it, Jerry Garcia did not
die on August 8th, 1995.

He died the very next day which was also the same exact day that Netscape
went public, August 9th, 1995, which I quite clearly recall as being the day
that the the starting gun went off with a loud and dramatic BANG! that was
the birth-pang of the Commercial Internets.

Incredibly heady time to be living in Silicon Valley, glad I was there for
that, even if I didn't walk away with a multi-billion dollar fortune.

The joke at the time with my friends in the investment community was that
Jerry Garcia's Last Words that day were:

Netscape opened at....

**WHAAAT!?!?11!!!**

Herein endeth the History Lesson.

.

On Nov 5, 2008, at 5:06 PM, Deepfog wrote:

>
>
> Anyone surprised on this Prop 8 passing?  I am.  I have trouble  
> believing it passed by such a wide margin.
>

Really?  Consider the demographic the Obama vote brought to the polls.  
Look at the exit poll data:  http://www.cnn.com/ELECTION/2008/results/polls/#CAI01p1

Fortunately SF, LA and Santa Clara City Attorney offices are  
challenging the constitutionality of the proposition.

I am really angry and hurt over this rejection. All my life I have  
struggled with homophobia and bigotry...and it ain't over yet!!!! BTW,  
fuck the Holy Name Society and the Catholic Church amongst others. Way  
past time to tax the churches.




"We're all afloat in a boundless sea,
and the way we cope is by massing together in groups and pretending in  
unison that the situation is other than it is. We reinforce the  
illusion for each other. That's what a society really is, a little  
band of humanity huddled together against the specter of a pitch black  
sea. Everyone is treading water to keep their heads above the surface  
even though they have no reason to believe that the life they're  
preserving is better than the alternative they're avoiding. It's just  
that one is known and one is not. Fear of the unknown is what keeps  
everyone busily treading water. All fear is fear of the unknown. If  
someone in such a group of water-treaders betrays the group lie by  
speaking the truth of their situation, that person is called a  
heretic, and society reserves its most awful punishments for heretics.  
If someone decides to stop struggling and just sink or float away,  
every possible effort is made to stop him, not for the benefit of the  
individual, but for the benefit of the group. To deny at all costs the  
truth of the situation."

J.McKenna

Some very sad news.  My good friend Fraser Clark has been diagnosed =20
with inoperable cancer.  Fraser was a pioneer "raver" involved in both =20=

the UK and San Francisco rave communities.

I promised him to inform as many ravers as I can of the benefit to be =20=

held for him soon in London.  So here 'tis:

Megatripolis

Benefit Event for Legendary Party Promoter
Fraser Clark

Full Moon
Thursday 13th November 2008
Starting at 10pm and finishing at 6am.
Heaven Night Club, Villiers Street, London WC2N 6NG, UK

Dubbed the Timothy Leary of the e-generation, founding Zippie and =20
grandfather of Luminopolis, Fraser Clark, has recently been diagnosed =20=

with inoperable liver cancer and his time within this reality zone is =20=

possibly drawing to a close. A special one-off Megatripolis event will =20=

be held as a fundraiser for his specialist medical care.

In the late 1980's Fraser the creator and editor of the Encyclopaedia =20=

Psychedelica, (EPi) a London based magazine, which achieved =20
international recognition & wherein he developed the concept and =20
coined the phrase Zippie, with the idea of saving the planet, =20
encouraging a consciousness craze and to embrace technology.

Evolution followed in 1990 and was the flagship magazine of the rave =20
culture and gained wide recognition both here in the Uk and America, =20
thus paving the way for his next move into dance culture.

Megatripolis was founded in 1993 and was one of the first people to =20
recognise the synergy arising from combining New Age ideology with =20
Rave culture. Creating the first UK in-door festival where people were =20=

exposed to cross-cultural ideas and experiences.

Megatripolis was a pioneer of the "Parallel University", the concept =20
of offering live talks by philosophers, scientists and activists =20
(along with supporting literature) to club-goers. Visits from speakers =20=

such as Allen Ginsberg, Terence McKenna, George Monbiot, Howard Marks =20=

and Ram Dass were common.

Megatripolis spawned a thousand imitators and is perhaps Fraser Clarks =20=

most enduring legacy.

In the late 1990's, Fraser teamed up with the genius alternative =20
theatre writer / actor / director Ken Campbell to create The Warp =20
Experience, 24 hour stage play by Niel Oram, within a 24 hour trance =20
party.

The Warp Experience was based at The Drome - the cavernous tunnels =20
under London Bridge Station now known as seOne. After it finished, a =20
number of the production crew went on to create The Synergy Project  - =20=

now known as Luminopolis.

Fraser's trailblazing has led directly to the amazing parties that we =20=

run today - he is our spiritual grandfather.

***

The Line-up

The main room . . . .

Cathedral

DJ=91s playing Shamanic + Mega =96T classics only.

22:00 =96 23:30   Darius Akasaic

23:30 =96 1:00     Richard Gray

1:00 - 1:30        A Miracle on the Dance Floor?
Everyone who wishes will gather on the main Heaven dance floor to Love =20=

bomb the man who started it all.

Love is the only answer, and this could be a hugely powerful =20
application of applied love our love will flow to Fraser as deep and =20
holy healing, surround and overwhelm him!  He will absorb it and allow =20=

it to work within him, bathing all his cells in golden light.  As he =20
sends the love back out to us, we will visualise the flow of golden =20
energy radiating out, healing, carrying all dis-ease with it, =20
transforming discomfort into joy and worries into peace, activating a =20=

beautiful Circle of Love that will flow out through London, the =20
planet's Heart Chakra. This is our time.  Fraser will no doubt ascend =20=

to Higher Heaven at this point, disappearing in a lightning flash! (TBC)

1:30 =96 4:00     Marco Arnaldi

4:00 - 5.30     Nic The Record

5.30 =96 6.30      All the above DJ=92s will play 1 record each in =
rotation.

Megatripolis

3rd room . . . .

Techno Silence Suite

A Celebration & investigation of the life, work and ideas of Fraser =20
Clark, a giant of the Counter Culture and Shamanarchic Rave Scene. We =20=

will talk, discuss, network, meditate, pray, and even dare to be silent.

Is Fraser now being proved right in predicting (and advocating) the =20
extinction of Dinosaur culture?

Did the old hippy/raver/tribal elder get it right?!  As Western =20
Capitalism flounders, will the New Shamanarchic Paradigm come to the =20
fore and a more loving, harmonious, inner-travelling and non-=20
competitive world come into being in our lifetime?  How exactly will =20
this scenario play out?


Panellists

Mark Heley, Kate Magic and other thinkers plus (health allowing)
Fraser himself.


MEGATRIP FOREVER TRIBUTE: Friends, colleagues and allies of Fraser =20
will talk about his personal influence on their lives and ideas. =20
Audience contribution encouraged. [The MEMORY WALL will be created =20
here, so please bring images, flyers etc from past events]


MEGATRIPOLIS FOREVER BOOK:  Kate Magic will talk about her forthcoming =20=

book 1988: The Untold Story of a Revolution, focusing on her chapter =20
on Fraser and his concepts etc.

Megatrip Forever Meditation & Prayer:  Spiritual groups will be =20
onstage to pray for Fraser's health and vitality to be restored.

Megatrip Forever Theatre: Performances from both Neil Oram's The WARP =20=

play, and Fraser's own coming MEGATRIPOLIS@FOREVER RAVE HOPERA.

Megatrip Forever Poetry: Poets will recite poems related to Fraser's =20
life, work and person.

Megatrip Forever Film: A shamanic theme in our surprise film premi=E8re. =
=20
Expect to go on a journey.

Megatripolis Forever Connections: All night we'll be meeting, RE-=20
CONNECTING, networking, and, dare I say it, loving each other.

Featured Performers

"We're all afloat in a boundless sea,
and the way we cope is by massing together in groups and pretending in =20=

unison that the situation is other than it is. We reinforce the =20
illusion for each other. That's what a society really is, a little =20
band of humanity huddled together against the specter of a pitch black =20=

sea. Everyone is treading water to keep their heads above the surface =20=

even though they have no reason to believe that the life they're =20
preserving is better than the alternative they're avoiding. It's just =20=

that one is known and one is not. Fear of the unknown is what keeps =20
everyone busily treading water. All fear is fear of the unknown. If =20
someone in such a group of water-treaders betrays the group lie by =20
speaking the truth of their situation, that person is called a =20
heretic, and society reserves its most awful punishments for heretics. =20=

If someone decides to stop struggling and just sink or float away, =20
every possible effort is made to stop him, not for the benefit of the =20=

individual, but for the benefit of the group. To deny at all costs the =20=

truth of the situation."

J.McKenna

This is what the love of my life for the past 15 years, Terri, had to =
say about Prop 8's passage.=20


Sent: Wednesday, November 05, 2008 2:18 PM
Subject: Congratulations my Friends!


      Here are my thoughts on things, whether or not you want to know =
what I think ;)



      Congratulations California!



      We can now join alongside countries such as Honduras, Latvia and =
Uganda in denying same-sex marriage rights.  We can stand proudly beside =
these nations and join in with their illustrious history of  bigotry and =
tyranny.  Honduras, the country who was reported on for human rights =
violations by the United Nations World Organization Against Torture =
(OMTC), has clearly and unequivocally banned same-sex marriage in 2005.  =
Latvia joined in at the same time, a country noted by the U.S. =
Department of State to have significant problems with police brutality =
and violence against women and children.  And let=92s not forget Uganda, =
where the atrocities are so common and far-flung it would take pages to =
document them.  Now, we can stand beside them in banning same-sex =
marriage.  And if we want to go the whole route, we can actually follow =
Uganda=92s lead and enact penalties for same sex marriage.  Maybe =
we=92ll have storylines like this from The African News Agency: =9318 =
September 2008: Turmoil has erupted once again in Uganda [California] as =
police clamp down on homosexuals in that country [state], which started =
this Monday 15 September [whenever].=94 =20

      =20

      Too bad for countries like Canada, Norway, The Netherlands, =
Belgium and Spain who have embraced same-sex marriage laws.  We =
Californians just obviously have some serious moral issues with you =
guys.  We would rather enact constitutional changes that ally us with =
countries that are a bit more=85..selective in their morals.=20

      =20

      Let=92s just face it, we really don=92t have much in common with =
you guys.   Canada, we=92ve always been annoyed that you are higher up =
on the planet than us anyway.  Besides, we like the idea of having an =
institution that is more like a Country Club.  It=92s exclusive, =
expensive and makes us feel safe.=20

      =20

      Yes, indeed, it is quite a day to celebrate, isn=92t it? =20

      =20

      =20

      On another note:  Those of you who feel  frustrated, singled-out =
and hurt by this Proposition of H8, do not despair!  Prohibition =
didn=92t last long either and hopefully people will wake up and realize =
that this is wrong before too much damage is done to us as a culture and =
a society.  Remember, God loves you too or our community wouldn=92t =
thrive with intelligent, loving and creative people the way that it =
does.   We are a bright jewel in this crown and we must continue to =
believe in ourselves and what we can achieve.  Our straight friends will =
perhaps join us in this fight like many of them have already.  Maybe we =
should *all* reconsider this idea of =93marriage=94 and whether or not =
we want it at all.  Perhaps we can come up with something more inclusive =
and loving that does not have roots in ownership and abuse. =20

      =20

      If we all stand together, we can create something even better and =
more beautiful than the traditional institution of exclusivity. =20

      =20

      Yes we can.=20
    =20

To be honest, based on who was backing 8, I'm surprised the prop didn't read
"A man, and as many woman and little girls as he wants". Based on our
experiences getting same-sex marriage instituted as a constitutional right
in South Africa, I know its no real consolation, but the long and hard fight
against the religious whack jobs was eventually won. The courts, in all good
conscience, cannot allow bigotry and inequality to be written into the
constitution. Just have to stay positive, and keep fighting.

On Wed, Nov 5, 2008 at 6:11 PM, Apollo <djapollo2k@mac.com> wrote:

>

> the constitutionality of the proposition.

> struggled with homophobia and bigotry...and it ain't over yet!!!! BTW, fuck
> the Holy Name Society and the Catholic Church amongst others. Way past time
> to tax the churches.
>
>
>
>
> "We're all afloat in a boundless sea,
> and the way we cope is by massing together in groups and pretending in
> unison that the situation is other than it is. We reinforce the illusion for
> each other. That's what a society really is, a little band of humanity
> huddled together against the specter of a pitch black sea. Everyone is
> treading water to keep their heads above the surface even though they have
> no reason to believe that the life they're preserving is better than the
> alternative they're avoiding. It's just that one is known and one is not.
> Fear of the unknown is what keeps everyone busily treading water. All fear
> is fear of the unknown. If someone in such a group of water-treaders betrays
> the group lie by speaking the truth of their situation, that person is
> called a heretic, and society reserves its most awful punishments for
> heretics. If someone decides to stop struggling and just sink or float away,
> every possible effort is made to stop him, not for the benefit of the
> individual, but for the benefit of the group. To deny at all costs the truth
> of the situation."
>
> J.McKenna

Here's a classic QOD for anyone that bangs their head against the wall =20
wondering why they can't convince people of the obvious.

*Fortunately* the Obamabot revolution was in no way a landslide.  Now =20
it is time to regroup for a united front against facism.  More later.

--

William James, father of American psychology, tells of meeting an old =20
lady who told him the Earth rested on the back of a huge turtle.

"But, my dear lady," Professor James asked, as politely as possible, =20
"what holds up the turtle?"

"Ah," she said, "that's easy.  He is standing on the back of another turtle.=
"

"Oh, I see," said Professor James, still being polite.  "But would you =20
be so good as to tell me what holds up the second turtle?"

"It's no use, Professor," said the old lady, realizing he was trying =20
to lead her into a logical trap.  "It's turtles-turtles-turtles, all =20
the way!"

Don't be too quick to laugh at the little old lady.  All human minds =20
work on fundamentally similar principles.  Her universe was a little =20
bit weirder than most but it was built up on the same mental =20
principles as every other universe people have believed in.

- Robert Anton Wilson (RIP)

Source:  Prometheus Rising, page 25

"Automatic" by LagWagon

wash your hair=2C bleach your teeth

Develop habit=2C=20

Automatic=20



Compromise=2C build a bridge=2C=20

Sacrifice=2C sacrilege=20

Sell yourself=2C=20

Automatic



Nobody out there knows=20

None of them have intent

Pretension and purpose=20

Fashioned in plastic heads

Everyone drives all day=20

None of them have a goal

Everyone lost their way=20

All of them play the game

=20

Set a goal=20

Make it happen=20

Imagine love=20

Fake a passion

Change your name=20

Stay in fashion=20

Make a deal=20

Make it happen

Compromise=2C build a bridge

Sacrifice=2C sacrilege



Same cars=20

Same clothes=20

Same desires=20

Same woes=20

Lose it all=20

Automatic



Nobody out there feels=20

None of them sees the end=20

Pretension and purpose

Fashioning in plastic heads=20

Everyone drives all day

Searching their empty hearts=20

Everyone's lost their way

All of us fall apart

=20

Automatic=20

Automatic

he planet, encouraging a consciousness craze and to embrace technology.=0A=

ture and gained wide recognition both here in the Uk and America, thus pavi=

ded in 1993 and was one of the first people to recognise the synergy arisin=
g from combining New Age ideology with Rave culture. Creating the first UK =
in-door festival where people were exposed to cross-cultural ideas and expe=
riences.=0A=0AMegatripolis was a pioneer of the "Parallel University", the =
concept of offering live talks by philosophers, scientists and activists (a=
long with supporting literature) to club-goers. Visits from speakers such a=
s Allen Ginsberg, Terence McKenna, George Monbiot, Howard Marks and Ram Das=
s were common.=0A=0AMegatripolis spawned a thousand imitators and is perhap=
s Fraser Clarks most enduring legacy.=0A=0AIn the late 1990's, Fraser teame=

bell to create The Warp Experience, 24 hour stage play by Niel Oram, within=
 a 24 hour trance party.=0A=0AThe Warp Experience was based at The Drome - =
the cavernous tunnels under London Bridge Station now known as seOne. After=
 it finished, a number of the production crew went on to create The Synergy=
 Project  - now known as Luminopolis.=0A=0AFraser's trailblazing has led di=

are available at:=0Ahttp://www.onlinestall.com/cgi-bin/stall2.pl?act=3Dep&i=

676148=0A=0A=0A=0A=0A"We're all afloat in a boundless sea,=0Aand the way we=
 cope is by massing together in groups and pretending in unison that the si=
tuation is other than it is. We reinforce the illusion for each other. That=
's what a society really is, a little band of humanity huddled together aga=
inst the specter of a pitch black sea. Everyone is treading water to keep t=
heir heads above the surface even though they have no reason to believe tha=
t the life they're preserving is better than the alternative they're avoidi=
ng. It's just that one is known and one is not. Fear of the unknown is what=
 keeps everyone busily treading water. All fear is fear of the unknown. If =
someone in such a group of water-treaders betrays the group lie by speaking=
 the truth of their situation, that person is called a heretic, and society=
 reserves its most awful punishments for heretics. If someone decides to st=
op struggling and just sink or float away, every possible effort is made to=
 stop him, not for the benefit of the individual, but
 for the benefit of the group. To deny at all costs the truth of the situat=
ion."=0A=0AJ.McKenna

As usual your comments are worthless and ignorant. There is a perfect place
you could move and have no government intervention or income tax. In fact, I
think you deserve to move there. It is a small swath of mountains in between
Afghanistan and the controlled portions of Pakistan. Not only is your
thinking in line with the people that inhabit the area, all your dreams of
anarchy, race supremacy, male dominance, and the lack of the IRS could be
had.
It always amazes me that the people  who contribute the least to society in
general, live in the tax-free poverty segment of the economy, use the roads,
rely on police to keep them safe from their neighbors, etc... are often the
ones who lambast the "system" that protects them and gives them roads,
lighting, and enough oversight to just be.

As a philosopher once said to an ignorant man: "You are smart, like tick on
stuffed animal."

Actually that's the reminder of how irrelevant SF is when the rest of the
state shows up.  prop8 won by over half a million votes.  Even if every
registered voter in SF had showed up and voted no, it wouldn't be enough
to change the statewide vote.

OTOH, it does show a direct age split on votes, so in 2-4 years the majority
will swing over anyway.  Just a matter of waiting a while.  DOMA will take
a while past that, of course.


-R.

On Thu, Nov 06, 2008 at 02:34:12PM -0800, dangrsmind@yahoo.com wrote:
> Ray's right. 
> Change is coming alright, but we maystill have to wait a bit longer for it to get here.
> What we are seeing right now in America is largely a generational shift and is going to play out over the next decade or so. 
> 
> On the night of the election on CNN they discussed this very issue.
> 
> Voters that said that race was a factor in their decision voted (statistically) the same as those who said race did not matter. Both groups favored Obama slightly and by almost exactly the same amount. Conclusion: racial preference was not a deciding factor in the election.
> 
> However there was a larger difference based on age. Older people tended to favor McCain and there was a very large difference between how the under 35 and over 65 groups voted. Conclusion: Age was a very significant indicator of beliefs, and the oldest and youngest groups essentially voted opposite to each other.
> 
> This was all based on election night exit poll results FWIW.
> 
> Best,
> 
> Peter

Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR: Political (was Re: [sfraves] (nrr) QOD (Wed))

They way I've explained it to a few people...  here's how the No on 8 
crowd should fight it...  they won't, because honestly, politically 
active gays are very big on in your face media circus bang on drum 
tactics...  attention whoreing...  it works for some issues...  but not all.

My recommendation is do not fight it in the courts.  The only people 
that win are the lawyers.  Keep your money.

Instead, start collecting signatures now, for a proposition to over turn 
the California constitutional amendment.  Get sigs now, and QUIETLY put 
on the minor election in two years. The reason is you get lowest voting 
turn out in a minor election.  At best, 8% registered.  That means to 
pass something you only need a 5% yes vote.  What you then get is a 
situation that the US constitution has with Amendment 18 & 21: 
Prohibition.  One will overturn the other. 

After that, there is no chance of changing it again.  At that point if 
they try another amendment you simply go to a court and have it removed 
from the ballot.

That's called working within the system, using the same tactics back at 
somebody.

I wouldn't even put billboards up.  You could set up hone centers and 
just call everyone in the gay business directory, tell them to vote and 
to tell their friends, but that it's being kept quiet to stay under the 
radar of opposition.

> Ray's right.

> Voters that said that race was a factor in their decision voted (statistically) the same as those who said race did not matter.  Both groups favored Obama slightly and by almost exactly the same amount.  Conclusion: racial preference was not a deciding factor in the election.
>
> However there was a larger difference based on age.  Older people tended to favor McCain and there was a very large difference between how the under 35 and over 65 groups voted.  Conclusion: Age was a very significant indicator of beliefs, and the oldest and youngest groups essentially voted opposite to each other.

> This was all based on election night exit poll results FWIW.

to favor McCain and there was a very large difference between how the under=
 35 and over 65 groups voted.  Conclusion: Age was a very significant indic=
ator of beliefs=2C and the oldest and youngest groups essentially voted opp=
osite to each other.
>=20
> This was all based on election night exit poll results FWIW.
>=20

Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR: Political (was Re: [sfraves] (nrr) QOD (Wed))



Beyond quietly, you can almost always bet that if there's a big ole
contraversy all over the news, that there's serious shit going on while
everyone's looking in the wrong direction at the shiny thing.  It's
pretty clear that the conservatives are always keeping a paranoid eye
out for the [gay|liberal|atheist|commie|whatever] agenda, but if their
attention can be turned to other things, that also works.

The hard part about doing during an off-year election is making sure you
get your base to show up while no one else is noticing.  That's actually
harder than it sounds.  Just look at how hard it can be to pull everyone
together for something simple like planning a party, and multiply.  You'll
get a lot of folks you call who say "yeah I'll be there" but unless there's
a public furor to motivate them, they tend to stay home anyway.


-R.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR: Political (was Re: [sfraves] (nrr) QOD (Wed))

True, but never underestimate the gaynetwork to rally the troops!  ;)  
Plus, a party is one thing, a quick call about a voting issues, a few 
emails and list placements in hot spots and the word gets out quickly. 

The tactic of off elections has been used for a long time.  You will see 
more props and measures on a primary or off year election than on a 
General.  I've had 12 page ballots (doubles sided) in the past non 
primary non general election before.

If the sig's are collected now and sat on, then it's really quiet.  I'v 
seen the online petition circulating and I have to laugh...  do those 
things ever accomplish anything except for consumer products?

>>> Date: Thu, 6 Nov 2008 14:48:16 -0800

>>> They way I've explained it to a few people...  here's how the No on 8 
>>> crowd should fight it...  they won't, because honestly, politically 
>>> active gays are very big on in your face media circus bang on drum 
>>> tactics...  attention whoreing...  it works for some issues...  but not all.
>>>
>>> My recommendation is do not fight it in the courts.  The only people 
>>> that win are the lawyers.  Keep your money.
>>>
>>> Instead, start collecting signatures now, for a proposition to over turn 
>>> the California constitutional amendment.  Get sigs now, and QUIETLY put 
>>> on the minor election in two years. The reason is you get lowest voting 
>>> turn out in a minor election.  At best, 8% registered.  That means to 
>>> pass something you only need a 5% yes vote.  What you then get is a 
>>> situation that the US constitution has with Amendment 18 & 21: 
>>> Prohibition.  One will overturn the other. 
>>>
>>> After that, there is no chance of changing it again.  At that point if 
>>> they try another amendment you simply go to a court and have it removed 
>>> from the ballot.
>>>
>>> That's called working within the system, using the same tactics back at 
>>> somebody.
>>>
>>> I wouldn't even put billboards up.  You could set up hone centers and 
>>> just call everyone in the gay business directory, tell them to vote and 
>>> to tell their friends, but that it's being kept quiet to stay under the 
>>> radar of opposition.

>>> dangrsmind@yahoo.com wrote:
>>>       
>>>> Ray's right.  
>>>> Change is coming alright, but we may still have to wait a bit longer for it to get here.
>>>> What we are seeing right now in America is largely a generational shift and is going to play out over the next decade or so.  
>>>>
>>>> On the night of the election on CNN they discussed this very issue.
>>>>
>>>> Voters that said that race was a factor in their decision voted (statistically) the same as those who said race did not matter.  Both groups favored Obama slightly and by almost exactly the same amount.  Conclusion: racial preference was not a deciding factor in the election.
>>>>
>>>> However there was a larger difference based on age.  Older people tended to favor McCain and there was a very large difference between how the under 35 and over 65 groups voted.  Conclusion: Age was a very significant indicator of beliefs, and the oldest and youngest groups essentially voted opposite to each other.
>>>>
>>>> This was all based on election night exit poll results FWIW.
>>>>
>>>> Best,
>>>>

> ---------------------------------------------------------------------
> To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
> For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org
>

"We're all afloat in a boundless sea,
and the way we cope is by massing together in groups and pretending in  
unison that the situation is other than it is. We reinforce the  
illusion for each other. That's what a society really is, a little  
band of humanity huddled together against the specter of a pitch black  
sea. Everyone is treading water to keep their heads above the surface  
even though they have no reason to believe that the life they're  
preserving is better than the alternative they're avoiding. It's just  
that one is known and one is not. Fear of the unknown is what keeps  
everyone busily treading water. All fear is fear of the unknown. If  
someone in such a group of water-treaders betrays the group lie by  
speaking the truth of their situation, that person is called a  
heretic, and society reserves its most awful punishments for heretics.  
If someone decides to stop struggling and just sink or float away,  
every possible effort is made to stop him, not for the benefit of the  
individual, but for the benefit of the group. To deny at all costs the  
truth of the situation."

J.McKenna


---------------------------------------------------------------------
To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

Subject: [sfraves] freeeeee record release party this saturday!!


http://www.cubikandorigami.com/wp-content/uploads/2008/11/co-release-party.jpg

******************

Come join Cubik and Origami on Saturday, November 8 as they
celebrate the release of Slept in on Doomsday, their new album
on Dinner Party Records.

We'll be playing along with some other great live acts and DJs.
Expect a night of top-notch downtempo, midtempo, IDM, electro,
dubstep and more. Featuring:

Cubik and Origami  - Live (Dinner Party) 
http://www.cubikandorigami.com/media
Dr. Toast - Live (False Profit) - http://www.drtoast.com
Comma  Live (Slidecamp)   http://www.staylucid.com
Redstickman (Ambient Mafia)  http://www.redstickman.com/
L'Aural and Daps  DJ set with live violin (Langton)
Shawn Allen (Dinner Party)  http://www.myspace.com/compulse

We'll have our new album available, as well as some fresh
merchandise:
http://dinnerpartyrecords.bigcartel.com/

Those who come best dressed for Doomsday will receive special
gift packs!

Where: Langton Labs  #9 Langton, San Francisco (Langton is an
alley that connects Howard and Folsom, and is in between 7th
and 8th Streets in SOMA).
When: Saturday, November 8. 10pm until later
How much: Free!
For more, see: http://www.cubikandorigami.com and
http://www.dinnerpartyrecords.com

A message from our hosts:
"Dear party guests - please respect our neighbors! In order for
Langton to continue throwing
awesome events, we must maintain good neighbor relations. Keep
our street quiet so that they can sleep while we party the
night away. That means absolutely no hanging out/making noise
in front of Langton Labs. If you want fresh air, a smoke break,
or a quiet conversation, please walk to either end of Langton
St."

Date: Thu, 6 Nov 2008 18:48:11 -0800
References: <20081105170616.bb2smhwce9a8scs0@webmail.deepfog.com> <B9133ECE-C501-4175-AE65-B7A4C864C9A6@mac.com> <BLU108-W12CB8366ABE4B883E7E3EF851E0@phx.gbl>

From: John B <svnlyrbrto@gmail.com>
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] (nrr) QOD (Wed)

I like the sentiment.  And a certain vicarious part was hoping to see  
some churches burn last night.  But the truth is, evil bigots though  
they may be, the xtians... catholics in particular... DO have a nice  
sense for architecture.  And converted churches have, in the past,  
made for some pretty cool clubs and loft apartments.

The clergy, OTOH...  There was a slogan during the french revolution:  
"Mankind will not be truly free until the last king is strangled with  
the entrails of the last priest."

We've divested ourselves of most of our kings.  This prop 8 business  
is a better illustration than any that it's well past time to start on  
the priests.

This is just utterly sickening, depressing, and more than a bit  
scary... walking down the streets throughout the day knowing for sure  
now that more than half of the people I see want me dead.  Though  
maybe the antipathy I would return towards them, if I knew which were  
which, makes me not much better I don't know.  It doesn't help that  
I've ALREADY been going through another bout of chronic insomnia and  
the lack of sleep has me on edge as it is.

But so help me... this last day or so I've actually been starting to  
think that maybe the Pink Pistols are right, and it'd be best to be  
prepared to do unto them, in case they get it in their head to do unto  
me.


cya,
john

>> challenging the constitutionality of the proposition.
>>
>> I am really angry and hurt over this rejection. All my life I have
>> struggled with homophobia and bigotry...and it ain't over yet!!!!  
>> BTW,
>> fuck the Holy Name Society and the Catholic Church amongst others.  
>> Way
>> past time to tax the churches.
>>
>>
>>
>>
>> "We're all afloat in a boundless sea,
>> and the way we cope is by massing together in groups and pretending  
>> in
>> unison that the situation is other than it is. We reinforce the
>> illusion for each other. That's what a society really is, a little
>> band of humanity huddled together against the specter of a pitch  
>> black
>> sea. Everyone is treading water to keep their heads above the surface
>> even though they have no reason to believe that the life they're
>> preserving is better than the alternative they're avoiding. It's just
>> that one is known and one is not. Fear of the unknown is what keeps
>> everyone busily treading water. All fear is fear of the unknown. If
>> someone in such a group of water-treaders betrays the group lie by
>> speaking the truth of their situation, that person is called a
>> heretic, and society reserves its most awful punishments for  
>> heretics.
>> If someone decides to stop struggling and just sink or float away,
>> every possible effort is made to stop him, not for the benefit of the
>> individual, but for the benefit of the group. To deny at all costs  
>> the
>> truth of the situation."
>>
>> J.McKenna
>>
>>

Subject: [sfraves] [BSP] Tomorrow! new party @ Julie's 1123 Folsom/7th SF

--qjSZefE6w0iW6XmQ
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Disposition: inline


Friday, 7 November 2008

NEW PARTY! NEW VENUE!  From those who brought you THIRSTY, FAKTION and others! 

M O L E K U L E

Friday, 7 November 2008:
Main Room:
FARZANA: Classy Concepts|3 Merry Men Be We 
AMBER: Thirsty|SisterSF
KENNETH SCOTT: Auralism|Nightlight|Binary

DownTempo:
STML: DEF
TOMKAT
SAIMAN

visuals by HEROIC ROBOT
live webcast via Radio Integrated!


Julie's Supperclub
1123 Folsom Street, San Francisco, CA
9 PM to 2 AM 21+
Cost: $5 after 10pm.

 

STML: STML's vast knowledge of music, technical ear and mixing talent are
immediately noticeable once he steps behind the decks.  Taking a subtractive
approach to mixing, STML prefers to keep it cool while taking you to places
in techno that are often unfamiliar... yet at the same time oh so sick!

Amber:  For over 10 years, Amber has served it up "music first," relying on
aggressive mixing of new and classic tracks instead of gimmickry or hype. 
Amber has played at all of SF's leading clubs, Ruby Skye, 1015, Supperclub
as well as countless undergrounds.

Farzana left her native Detroit to be part of San Francisco's Techno rebirth
2 years ago.  Having built a reputation for dark, dirty and funky, her love
affair with techno looks to continue heating up for many years to come.

Kenneth Scott, aka Eutactic cites as his influence early Warp records, Matthew
Dear's acid experimentation as Audion and minimal-minded composers such as
Philip Glass and Arvo Part.  Defying categorization, he combines hard and
melodic into his own unique style.



--qjSZefE6w0iW6XmQ

Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR: Political (was Re: [sfraves] (nrr) QOD (Wed))

Interestingly, but perhaps not surprisingly, it appears that voting on Proposition 8 was highly correlated with race.

"Seven in 10 African Americans who went to the polls voted yes on
Proposition 8, the ballot measure overruling a state Supreme Court
judgment that legalized same-sex marriage and brought 18,000 gay and
lesbian couples to Golden State courthouses in the past six months."

>From http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2008/11/06/AR2008110603880.html?sub=AR

See also: http://www.afterelton.com/music/2006/6/hiphop.html

Regards,

Peter

From: "electrofunk138@hotmail.com" <electrofunk138@hotmail.com>

Sent: Thursday, November 6, 2008 2:49:28 PM
Subject: RE: [sfraves] NRR: Political (was Re: [sfraves] (nrr) QOD (Wed))




I'd say that's a very fair indicator. And just further helps me realize my theory that once the baby boomers are gone (from power), life will suck a lot less.



> Date: Thu, 6 Nov 2008 14:34:12 -0800
> From: dangrsmind@yahoo.com
> To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
> Subject: [sfraves] NRR: Political (was Re: [sfraves] (nrr) QOD (Wed))
> 
> Ray's right.  
> Change is coming alright, but we may still have to wait a bit longer for it to get here.
> What we are seeing right now in America is largely a generational shift and is going to play out over the next decade or so.  
> 
> On the night of the election on CNN they discussed this very issue.
> 
> Voters that said that race was a factor in their decision voted (statistically) the same as those who said race did not matter.  Both groups favored Obama slightly and by almost exactly the same amount.  Conclusion: racial preference was not a deciding factor in the election.
> 
> However there was a larger difference based on age.  Older people tended to favor McCain and there was a very large difference between how the under 35 and over 65 groups voted.  Conclusion: Age was a very significant indicator of beliefs, and the oldest and youngest groups essentially voted opposite to each other.
> 
> This was all based on election night exit poll results FWIW.
> 
> Best,
> 
> Peter
> 
> 
>

Subject: [sfraves] (nrr) QOD (Fri)

Good god, I cannot believe the DCRaves list.  I replied to one of the =20
threads last night, ended up spending most of the evening reading and =20
responding to the threads, then when I woke up this morning, 46 more =20
emails talking about this voluntary national service plan that Obama =20
has already rolled out.  Now that's a discussion.

And no one like Bill Haagen-Daas hiding in the shadows sending out =20
empty threats.  Who the hell are you, buddy?  I have a real problem =20
with the fact that apparently no one seems to know who you are.  Have =20
you ever even been to a rave, or are you someone hired by the =20
government to hang out on the internet all day, be a blowhard, and =20
disrupt free thinking conversations?  If that's all you're here for, I =20
think you're going to find you're not going to get much attention here.

All you've had to say are these demands that I shut up.  What if I =20
don't?  Are you going to come to my house and beat me up?  Should I =20
wear a bulletproof vest to the next rave I go to?  If I take your =20
email address of my spam filter, what kind of threatening private =20
emails am I going to see if you don't get your way? We've heard your =20
point of view and since you seem to have no other, how about =20
identifying yourself on the list, who you are and what crew you hail =20
from, if any?

Ethan.  Where's Ethan, dammit?  What was that he used to say when =20
unscrupulous people would throw parties, he'd demand they open the =20
books to everyone on the list.  So stop hiding in the shadows, Bill =20
Haagen-Daas, or whatever your name is, and introduce yourself.

I would like you, my friends on SFraves, to join me in a moment of =20
silence for Peace, Love, Unity, Respect.  PLUR.  Remember it, and try =20
to live by it when you can.  Everyone knows I've fallen off that track =20
more than once, but I would argue most of us have at one point or =20
another.  But I have always been a firm believer that the rave scene =20
can and will change the world a whole lot more than any politician =20
could.

Is anyone up for a road trip to DC to go to Transit some week?

--

How people treat you is their karma; how you react is yours.

- Wayne Dyer

Source:  http://thinkexist.com/quotes/with/keyword/karma/

>> Ray's right.
>> Change is coming alright, but we may still have to wait a bit longer for it to get here.
>> What we are seeing right now in America is largely a generational shift and is going to play out over the next decade or so.

>> On the night of the election on CNN they discussed this very issue.
>>
>> Voters that said that race was a factor in their decision voted (statistically) the same as those who said race did not matter.  Both groups favored Obama slightly and by almost exactly the same amount.  Conclusion: racial preference was not a deciding factor in the election.
>>
>> However there was a larger difference based on age.  Older people tended to favor McCain and there was a very large difference between how the under 35 and over 65 groups voted.  Conclusion: Age was a very significant indicator of beliefs, and the oldest and youngest groups essentially voted opposite to each other.
>>
>> This was all based on election night exit poll results FWIW.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR: Political (was Re: [sfraves] (nrr) QOD (Wed))


That's why I posted the exit polling data from CNN to this list.  The  
correlation is clear.  I knew it would be, because homophobia is  
rampant in the black community.  Has been for as long as I know.

One of the reasons the Paradise Garage was so successful. Those gay  
black kids had so many weights around their necks. The PG provided a  
brief but powerful opportunity to be free from the oppression of  
family, community and church.

I don't completely understand black homophobia. From what I know of  
tribal cultures, and I don't claim to have expertise here, being gay  
is not a negative in these communities. Some even value gays as  
shamans and the like. I think the homophobia in black American  
communities arises from the influence of various Christian Churches.

And then there is the very complex issue of prison sex. So many black  
males going through the system. There would be an area of very  
interesting study.

The highest rates of HIV infections in the USA is now amongst young  
gay black males. More victims of homophobia. Tragic.

Really, really irritates me that BO danced around the issue until  
after he won.  No mensch.  Just like any other politician.

As for the jerk who wished all the boomers dead because they were  
responsible for all our woes, ponder this:

"An open apology to boomers everywhere"
Your earnest, self-important prattle has gotten on Gen X nerves for  
decades. But now we finally get it.

By Heather Havrilesky

http://www.salon.com/mwt/feature/2008/11/07/havrilesky/index.html


Apollo

>

"We're all afloat in a boundless sea,
and the way we cope is by massing together in groups and pretending in  
unison that the situation is other than it is. We reinforce the  
illusion for each other. That's what a society really is, a little  
band of humanity huddled together against the specter of a pitch black  
sea. Everyone is treading water to keep their heads above the surface  
even though they have no reason to believe that the life they're  
preserving is better than the alternative they're avoiding. It's just  
that one is known and one is not. Fear of the unknown is what keeps  
everyone busily treading water. All fear is fear of the unknown. If  
someone in such a group of water-treaders betrays the group lie by  
speaking the truth of their situation, that person is called a  
heretic, and society reserves its most awful punishments for heretics.  
If someone decides to stop struggling and just sink or float away,  
every possible effort is made to stop him, not for the benefit of the  
individual, but for the benefit of the group. To deny at all costs the  
truth of the situation."

J.McKenna


---------------------------------------------------------------------
To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

This could actually probably pass for punk with how balls to the wall it is=
 - but at any rate=2C it may strike some chords given the recent Prop 8 bul=
lshit that was shoved down our throats this week....

"RISE" by Pantera

We've got no time to lose=20

Your news is old news=20

Hate this=2C hate me=2C hate this=20

Right approach for the wrong=20

It's time to spread the word=20

Let the voice be heard=20

All of us=2C one of us=2C all of us=20

Dominate and take the motherfucking world=20



Mass prediction=2C unification=20

Breathing life into out lungs=20

EVERY creed and EVERY kind=20

To give us depth for strength=20



Taught when we're young to hate one another=20

It's time to have a new reign of power=20

Make pride universal so no one gives in=20

Turn our backs on those who oppose=20

Then when confronted we ask them the question=20

That's wrong with their mind?=20

What's wrong with your mind?=20



It's time to RISE=20



We've lived with past mistakes=20

Can we live with our own=20

Forgive=2C forget forgive=20

Be a man=2C not a child=20

There are no tears for peace=20

Of the common sympathies=20

Educate=2C reinstate=2C educate=20

A thing of past=20

The trouble in the states=20



It's time to RISE!!!!

------=_Part_30854_26243116.1226094207092
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=ISO-8859-1
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Content-Disposition: inline

It's worth noting that the gay community did *not* make any inroads into the
black community in drumming up support for this proposition.

There were no anti-prop 8 rallies in Oakland, for example. Also, the
campaign ads (civil rights collage narrated by Samuel L Jackson) they ran in
the last few days running up to the election were perceived by most black
people as incredibly patronizing. Who the fuck are these white fags to go
around telling a bunch of black people about what's a civil rights issue and
what's not? A friend of a friend is an activist in Oakland (black, and gay),
he wrote a very interesting piece on this issue, I'll see if I can find it
and send the link. It's enlightening.

I'm not saying that gay marriage isn't a civil rights issue, but you don't
just go to someone, say 'THIS IS A CIVIL RIGHTS ISSUE, NOW GET BEHIND IT'
and expect them to go running to the fucking polls for you. Especially when
that someone you're trying to say this to has been systematically oppressed
for the last 400 years. There was *no* serious attempt by the gay community
to reach out to black voters for most of the campaign, and in fact the only
attempt they did make was half hearted and patronizing as all hell. It's a
sad, sad day for gay folks everywhere in California, BUT don't go blaming
the black community for this shit.

For the record, I voted no on 8, I'm technically a fag myself (a woman can
eat a thousand pussies and not be a lesbian, but a man sucks 1 dick and he's
a fag for life), and I'm very unhappy with the result. The undercurrent of
racism in the gay community's response to the black voting stats is not,
however, acceptable.

On Fri, Nov 7, 2008 at 9:49 AM, Sean G <rationalhatter@gmail.com> wrote:

> a LOT of black and latin people (and one korean girl) I talked to said
> they were voting yes for religious reasons/'how they were raised'.
> people just dont think for themselves..
>

> > Interestingly, but perhaps not surprisingly, it appears that voting on
> Proposition 8 was highly correlated with race.
> >
> > "Seven in 10 African Americans who went to the polls voted yes on
> > Proposition 8, the ballot measure overruling a state Supreme Court
> > judgment that legalized same-sex marriage and brought 18,000 gay and
> > lesbian couples to Golden State courthouses in the past six months."
> >
> > From
> http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2008/11/06/AR2008110603880.html?sub=AR
> >
> > See also: http://www.afterelton.com/music/2006/6/hiphop.html
> >

Interesting.  

I expect to there will be an entertaining, oops I mean spirited, debate this Thanksgiving between my sister, her partner and my dad's idiotic Neo-con friends.    I'm going to need a lot of booze for this one.

Here's a recent article that my sister wrote that some might find interesting: http://www.huffingtonpost.com/jennifer-e-rothman/reality-check-why-opponen_b_139388.html  I think it has some weak points frankly.

Also, it seems to me that responding to Prop. 8 with an ad that essentially repeated the arguments of Prop. 8 supporters was not wise.  And the ad seemed to be directed at the wrong people; it seems to me that there was a failure to understand the correct target audience for the anti-8 campaign.  Preaching to the converted does not win close elections, you need to convert some of your opponents to your cause. 

An attempt to win over some African American voters could have been an important piece of that strategy.  But I don't plan on arguing with my sister about it.  I always lose.

Peter






----- Original Message ----
From: pinkko <ealaughlin@gmail.com>
To: SF Raves <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Sent: Friday, November 7, 2008 1:43:27 PM
Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR: Political (was Re: [sfraves] (nrr) QOD (Wed))

It's worth noting that the gay community did *not* make any inroads into the
black community in drumming up support for this proposition.

There were no anti-prop 8 rallies in Oakland, for example. Also, the
campaign ads (civil rights collage narrated by Samuel L Jackson) they ran in
the last few days running up to the election were perceived by most black
people as incredibly patronizing. Who the fuck are these white fags to go
around telling a bunch of black people about what's a civil rights issue and
what's not? A friend of a friend is an activist in Oakland (black, and gay),
he wrote a very interesting piece on this issue, I'll see if I can find it
and send the link. It's enlightening.

I'm not saying that gay marriage isn't a civil rights issue, but you don't
just go to someone, say 'THIS IS A CIVIL RIGHTS ISSUE, NOW GET BEHIND IT'
and expect them to go running to the fucking polls for you. Especially when
that someone you're trying to say this to has been systematically oppressed
for the last 400 years. There was *no* serious attempt by the gay community
to reach out to black voters for most of the campaign, and in fact the only
attempt they did make was half hearted and patronizing as all hell. It's a
sad, sad day for gay folks everywhere in California, BUT don't go blaming
the black community for this shit.

For the record, I voted no on 8, I'm technically a fag myself (a woman can
eat a thousand pussies and not be a lesbian, but a man sucks 1 dick and he's
a fag for life), and I'm very unhappy with the result. The undercurrent of
racism in the gay community's response to the black voting stats is not,
however, acceptable.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR: Political (was Re: [sfraves] (nrr) QOD (Wed))

Asian community as well.

I'm not attacking or stereotyping.  You all know where I work, and I
have a lot of opportunity to talk to a lot of people, about a lot of
things.  I've had conversations with Asians who openly point out that
they do not like (homosexuals) and are tired of dealing with them.  The
saving grace is that they make it clear they will leave them alone if
the same courtesy is given to them.

This is of course ironic since we host shangri'lah the biggest Asian
LBGT in San Francisco.

Further confirmation of this is a very big promoter approached me about
using the space (Adriana's support party location) about throwing a
private party for a group of gays who are want to party outside the
Castro and not have to deal with a bunch of Asians giving them problems.

So, let's be fair, homophobia isn't limited to the black community,
though the statistics show your thesis to hold water.

While it can't be said for many things, at least homophobia is color blind!

--S

Apollo wrote:
>
> That's why I posted the exit polling data from CNN to this list.  The
> correlation is clear.  I knew it would be, because homophobia is
> rampant in the black community.  Has been for as long as I know.
>
> One of the reasons the Paradise Garage was so successful. Those gay
> black kids had so many weights around their necks. The PG provided a
> brief but powerful opportunity to be free from the oppression of
> family, community and church.
>
> I don't completely understand black homophobia. From what I know of
> tribal cultures, and I don't claim to have expertise here, being gay
> is not a negative in these communities. Some even value gays as
> shamans and the like. I think the homophobia in black American
> communities arises from the influence of various Christian Churches.
>
> And then there is the very complex issue of prison sex. So many black
> males going through the system. There would be an area of very
> interesting study.
>
> The highest rates of HIV infections in the USA is now amongst young
> gay black males. More victims of homophobia. Tragic.
>
> Really, really irritates me that BO danced around the issue until
> after he won.  No mensch.  Just like any other politician.
>
> As for the jerk who wished all the boomers dead because they were
> responsible for all our woes, ponder this:
>

>>> Date: Thu, 6 Nov 2008 14:34:12 -0800

>>> Ray's right.
>>> Change is coming alright, but we may still have to wait a bit longer
>>> for it to get here.
>>> What we are seeing right now in America is largely a generational
>>> shift and is going to play out over the next decade or so.
>>>
>>> On the night of the election on CNN they discussed this very issue.
>>>
>>> Voters that said that race was a factor in their decision voted
>>> (statistically) the same as those who said race did not matter. 
>>> Both groups favored Obama slightly and by almost exactly the same
>>> amount.  Conclusion: racial preference was not a deciding factor in
>>> the election.
>>>
>>> However there was a larger difference based on age.  Older people
>>> tended to favor McCain and there was a very large difference between
>>> how the under 35 and over 65 groups voted.  Conclusion: Age was a
>>> very significant indicator of beliefs, and the oldest and youngest
>>> groups essentially voted opposite to each other.
>>>

>
> "We're all afloat in a boundless sea,
> and the way we cope is by massing together in groups and pretending in
> unison that the situation is other than it is. We reinforce the
> illusion for each other. That's what a society really is, a little
> band of humanity huddled together against the specter of a pitch black
> sea. Everyone is treading water to keep their heads above the surface
> even though they have no reason to believe that the life they're
> preserving is better than the alternative they're avoiding. It's just
> that one is known and one is not. Fear of the unknown is what keeps
> everyone busily treading water. All fear is fear of the unknown. If
> someone in such a group of water-treaders betrays the group lie by
> speaking the truth of their situation, that person is called a
> heretic, and society reserves its most awful punishments for heretics.
> If someone decides to stop struggling and just sink or float away,
> every possible effort is made to stop him, not for the benefit of the
> individual, but for the benefit of the group. To deny at all costs the
> truth of the situation."
>
> J.McKenna
>
>

should have been in quotes to be more appropriate.

on '03.

> > band of humanity huddled together against the specter of a pitch black
> > sea. Everyone is treading water to keep their heads above the surface
> > even though they have no reason to believe that the life they're
> > preserving is better than the alternative they're avoiding. It's just
> > that one is known and one is not. Fear of the unknown is what keeps
> > everyone busily treading water. All fear is fear of the unknown. If
> > someone in such a group of water-treaders betrays the group lie by
> > speaking the truth of their situation=2C that person is called a
> > heretic=2C and society reserves its most awful punishments for heretics=
.
> > If someone decides to stop struggling and just sink or float away=2C
> > every possible effort is made to stop him=2C not for the benefit of the
> > individual=2C but for the benefit of the group. To deny at all costs th=
e
> > truth of the situation."

Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR: Political (was Re: [sfraves] (nrr) QOD (Wed))

Ok, having total family guy moment with Brians gay cousin now.

The problem with exit polls is they are based only on peopel who are
willing to fill out the questionare , so it's limited.

If only 5% of all voting Asians filled out the exit poll, that's not the
best statistical sample, other than to say "of Asians who are the type
to fill out an exit poll, X voted for 8".  In fact, I bet you could
statistically say with reasonable validity that black voters are more
likely to answer an exit poll by a margin of 2:1 over Asians.

I know people hate statistics, they're accurate when presented properly.

Now, you can then say that Asians, who are willing to answer an exit
poll, are more likely to vote no on 8 than Asians who are not willing to
answer an exit poll!  This is where you get into supposition and
assumption, without any statistical data support.

have I bored everyone to tears yet?

> > >> lesbian couples to Golden State courthouses in the past six months."

> > >>>
> > >>> Ray's right.
> > >>> Change is coming alright, but we may still have to wait a bit longer
> > >>> for it to get here.
> > >>> What we are seeing right now in America is largely a generational
> > >>> shift and is going to play out over the next decade or so.
> > >>>
> > >>> On the night of the election on CNN they discussed this very issue.
> > >>>
> > >>> Voters that said that race was a factor in their decision voted
> > >>> (statistically) the same as those who said race did not matter.
> > >>> Both groups favored Obama slightly and by almost exactly the same
> > >>> amount. Conclusion: racial preference was not a deciding factor in
> > >>> the election.
> > >>>
> > >>> However there was a larger difference based on age. Older people
> > >>> tended to favor McCain and there was a very large difference between
> > >>> how the under 35 and over 65 groups voted. Conclusion: Age was a
> > >>> very significant indicator of beliefs, and the oldest and youngest
> > >>> groups essentially voted opposite to each other.
> > >>>
> > >>> This was all based on election night exit poll results FWIW.
> > >>>
> > >>> Best,
> > >>>

> > >
> > > "We're all afloat in a boundless sea,
> > > and the way we cope is by massing together in groups and pretending in
> > > unison that the situation is other than it is. We reinforce the
> > > illusion for each other. That's what a society really is, a little
> > > band of humanity huddled together against the specter of a pitch black
> > > sea. Everyone is treading water to keep their heads above the surface
> > > even though they have no reason to believe that the life they're
> > > preserving is better than the alternative they're avoiding. It's just
> > > that one is known and one is not. Fear of the unknown is what keeps
> > > everyone busily treading water. All fear is fear of the unknown. If
> > > someone in such a group of water-treaders betrays the group lie by
> > > speaking the truth of their situation, that person is called a
> > > heretic, and society reserves its most awful punishments for heretics.
> > > If someone decides to stop struggling and just sink or float away,
> > > every possible effort is made to stop him, not for the benefit of the
> > > individual, but for the benefit of the group. To deny at all costs the
> > > truth of the situation."
> > >
> > > J.McKenna
> > >

Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR: Political (was Re: [sfraves] (nrr) QOD (Wed))

The problem is, all of the polling has a lot of margin for error. 

eg:  I'm the type to answer polls with a lie just cause I like to fuck
with people.  Now, they have a statistical base that they assume people
are doing that, and "adjust".  Much like a game of pool though, there's
only so many adjustments you can make before chaos takes over and resets
the table.  Add enough adjustments to statistical data and it's adjusted
to the point of not having a bit of validity anymore.

Thus,voting results are the only true test because it's anonymous.  They
only way you could get accurate voting results is of on the ballot they
had check boxes for "age, race, gender (M/F  sorry trannies), sexual
orientation (S/G/B)"

That would return interesting results, though I'm sure peopel would fear
their vote not being counted if they disclose that info.

dangrsmind@yahoo.com wrote:
> Well, most exit polls use stratified sampling.  Therefore they supposedly reweight the raw exit data to account for this sort of bias.  However if your previously calculated weights are incorrect, you will get similarly incorrect resultsthese may be very different from the true population's statistics depending.

>>>>>> Ray's right.
>>>>>> Change is coming alright, but we may still have to wait a bit longer
>>>>>> for it to get here.
>>>>>> What we are seeing right now in America is largely a generational

>>>>>> On the night of the election on CNN they discussed this very issue.
>>>>>>
>>>>>> Voters that said that race was a factor in their decision voted
>>>>>> (statistically) the same as those who said race did not matter.
>>>>>> Both groups favored Obama slightly and by almost exactly the same
>>>>>> amount. Conclusion: racial preference was not a deciding factor in
>>>>>> the election.
>>>>>>
>>>>>> However there was a larger difference based on age. Older people
>>>>>> tended to favor McCain and there was a very large difference between
>>>>>> how the under 35 and over 65 groups voted. Conclusion: Age was a
>>>>>> very significant indicator of beliefs, and the oldest and youngest
>>>>>> groups essentially voted opposite to each other.
>>>>>>
>>>>>> This was all based on election night exit poll results FWIW.

>>>> "We're all afloat in a boundless sea,
>>>> and the way we cope is by massing together in groups and pretending in
>>>> unison that the situation is other than it is. We reinforce the
>>>> illusion for each other. That's what a society really is, a little
>>>> band of humanity huddled together against the specter of a pitch black
>>>> sea. Everyone is treading water to keep their heads above the surface
>>>> even though they have no reason to believe that the life they're
>>>> preserving is better than the alternative they're avoiding. It's just
>>>> that one is known and one is not. Fear of the unknown is what keeps
>>>> everyone busily treading water. All fear is fear of the unknown. If
>>>> someone in such a group of water-treaders betrays the group lie by
>>>> speaking the truth of their situation, that person is called a
>>>> heretic, and society reserves its most awful punishments for heretics.
>>>> If someone decides to stop struggling and just sink or float away,
>>>> every possible effort is made to stop him, not for the benefit of the
>>>> individual, but for the benefit of the group. To deny at all costs the
>>>> truth of the situation."
>>>>
>>>> J.McKenna
>>>>

Years ago I told myself that if anyone ever calls me or my brothers  
and sisters "fag" or "faggot" again I would not allow the slurs to go  
unpunished.  You go into a black neighborhood and use the "n" word you  
crawl out disabled or end up in a body bag.  White folk have learned  
this.  Painful lessons seem to work in this fucked up world.  You got  
an atomic bomb folks take you seriously.  Xianity has had absolutely  
no positive effect on human behaviours.  On the contrary.

You have no right to call anyone bigoted names.  And I demand from the  
moderator that this derisive language be stopped on SF raves.  Pinkko  
isn't the only one to use it.

As for me, in the sixties when I was in high school I spent several  
summers battling for civil rights in the South.  Got beaten up.  Worse  
was when some folks dropped piss filled balloons on me and my "white  
fag" worker friends.  I have fought bigotry and discrimination all my  
life and I will continue to do so.  You're just another bigot no  
matter what you think of yourself.

I will have nothing more to do with you.  Finally, after all the  
ranting I've endured from you, you're on my trash on receipt list.

Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

The US is:  "...a nation of 200 million used-car salesmen with all the  
money we need to buy guns and no qualms about killing anybody else in  
the world who tries to make us uncomfortable."
-Hunter S. Thompson

"Friend, hope for the truth while you are alive.  Jump into experience  
while you are alive!  What you call "salvation" belongs to the time  
before death.  If you don't break your ropes while you are alive, do  
you think ghosts will do it after?"
-Kabir

YES

Srsly, tho, I'm not trying to say anything homophobic. What I'm saying is
that I'm disappointed in the gay community's reaction to prop 8 passing with
the overwhelming support of the black community when there were no real
attempts made at reaching out to that community. My feelings on this are
similar to the feelings a father would have after catching his teenage
daughter coming home after a night of drinking. . . I'm disappointed in the
response to this. It's shameful, and I am, as a gay (or at least not
straight, or at least not heteronormative) man, ashamed.

>>>>> racial preference was not a deciding factor in the election.

>>>>>>> people
>>>>>>> tended
>>>>>>>
>>>>>> to favor McCain and there was a very large difference between  
>>>>>> how the
>>>>> under
>>>>> 35 and over 65 groups voted.  Conclusion: Age was a very  
>>>>> significant
>>>>> indicator of beliefs, and the oldest and youngest groups  
>>>>> essentially
>>>>> voted
>>>>> opposite to each other.

>>>>>>>>>>
>>>>>>>>>>  under

>> very significant
>>>>>>>>> indicator of beliefs, and the oldest and youngest

>>>>>>>>> voted
>>>>>>>>> opposite to each other.
