> >>>>>>>>>>>
> >>>>>>>>>>> Voters that said that race was a factor in their
> >> decision voted
> >>>>>>>>>>>
> >>>>>>>>>>> (statistically) the same as those who said race
> did
> >> not matter.
> >>>>>>>>>>>
> >>>>>>>>>> Both
> >>>>>>>>>>
> >>>>>>>>>>  groups
> >>>>>>>>> favored Obama slightly and by almost exactly the
> same
> >> amount.
> >>>>>>>>> Conclusion:
> >>>>>>>>> racial preference was not a deciding factor in the
> >> election.
> >>>>>>>>>
> >>>>>>>>>
> >>>>>>>>>  However there was a larger difference based on
> age.
> >> Older people
> >>>>>>>>>>
> >>>>>>>>>>> tended
> >>>>>>>>>>>
> >>>>>>>>>>> to favor McCain and there was a very large
> >> difference between how
> >>>>>>>>>>>
> >>>>>>>>>> the
> >>>>>>>>>>
> >>>>>>>>>>  under
> >>>>>>>>> 35 and over 65 groups voted.  Conclusion: Age was a
> >> very significant
> >>>>>>>>> indicator of beliefs, and the oldest and youngest
> >> groups essentially
> >>>>>>>>> voted
> >>>>>>>>> opposite to each other.
> >>>>>>>>>
> >>>>>>>>>
> >>>>>>>>>  This was all based on election night exit poll
> >> results FWIW.
> >>>>>>>>>>
> >>>>>>>>>>>
> >>>>>>>>>>> Best,
> >>>>>>>>>>>
> >>>>>>>>>>> Peter
> >>>>>>>>>>>

>>>> this very issue.
>>>>>>>>>>>>
>>>>>>>>>>>>>
>>>>>>>>>>>>> Voters that said that race was a factor in their
>>>> decision voted
>>>>>>>>>>>>>
>>>>>>>>>>>>> (statistically) the same as those who said race
>> did
>>>> not matter.
>>>>>>>>>>>>>
>>>>>>>>>>>> Both
>>>>>>>>>>>>
>>>>>>>>>>>>  groups
>>>>>>>>>>> favored Obama slightly and by almost exactly the
>> same
>>>> amount.
>>>>>>>>>>> Conclusion:
>>>>>>>>>>> racial preference was not a deciding factor in the
>>>> election.
>>>>>>>>>>>
>>>>>>>>>>>
>>>>>>>>>>>  However there was a larger difference based on
>> age.
>>>> Older people
>>>>>>>>>>>>
>>>>>>>>>>>>> tended
>>>>>>>>>>>>>
>>>>>>>>>>>>> to favor McCain and there was a very large
>>>> difference between how
>>>>>>>>>>>>>
>>>>>>>>>>>> the
>>>>>>>>>>>>
>>>>>>>>>>>>  under
>>>>>>>>>>> 35 and over 65 groups voted.  Conclusion: Age was a
>>>> very significant
>>>>>>>>>>> indicator of beliefs, and the oldest and youngest
>>>> groups essentially
>>>>>>>>>>> voted
>>>>>>>>>>> opposite to each other.
>>>>>>>>>>>
>>>>>>>>>>>
>>>>>>>>>>>  This was all based on election night exit poll
>>>> results FWIW.

Molekle

FARZANA: Classy Concepts|3 Merry Men Be We 
KENNETH SCOTT: Auralism|Nightlight|Binary
ROBOTHEAD

STML: DEF
TOMKAT

Julie's Supperclub
1123 Folsom Street, San Francisco, CA
9 PM to 2 AM 21+
Cost: $5 after 10pm.

 

STML: STML's vast knowledge of music, technical ear and mixing talent are
immediately noticeable once he steps behind the decks.  Taking a subtractive
approach to mixing, STML prefers to keep it cool while taking you to places
in techno that are often unfamiliar... yet at the same time oh so sick!

Farzana left her native Detroit to be part of San Francisco's Techno rebirth
2 years ago.  Having built a reputation for dark, dirty and funky, her love
affair with techno looks to continue heating up for many years to come.

Kenneth Scott, aka Eutactic cites as his influence early Warp records, Matthew
Dear's acid experimentation as Audion and minimal-minded composers such as
Philip Glass and Arvo Part.  Defying categorization, he combines hard and
melodic into his own unique style.

Apollo wrote:
> You have no right to call anyone bigoted names.  And I demand 
> from the moderator that this derisive language be stopped on 
> SF raves. Pinkko isn't the only one to use it.

As much as I wish I could, can't censor any words on this list. 
All I can do is unsub people, limit posts, or shut off the list. 
I do believe, Apollo, that you felt personally attacked, and that is 
not okay.

Clearly emotions are running high in this 
uncertain political/civil-rights climate we are experiencing. 
And I know for some of you this is extremely personal.

Pinkko, I think it would be a good idea for you to apologize to 
Apollo, offlist perhaps. You already know your words can be 
abrasive, but in this particular context they are 
pretty distasteful, at best.

This pretty much goes for everyone. Again, I can't will the list 
into specific language, but I do ask everyone to think for a 
moment before they post, and remember there are real people on 
the other side of your screen.

-terry

Strictly for the Love

Please join us as we bring you two rooms of deep soulful beats until the wee
hours of the morning.  We've secured a beautiful new venue for this event,
complete with an outdoor patio, BBQ and plenty of parking.  Expect a mix of
live musicians, vocalists, and some of the best DJs in the Bay Area,
anchored by the incomparable David Harness (Super Soul Sundays) and
Trinidadian Deep (Prescription, Shelter).

Subject: [sfraves] NRR: More ways to fight back against the prop 8 bigots... 

--Apple-Mail-7-987319326
Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset=US-ASCII;
	format=flowed;
	delsp=yes
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

As part of campaign finance disclosure and transparency, the  
California Secretary of State's website provides the donor lists to  
the various yes on 8 PACs:

http://cal-access.ss.ca.gov/Campaign/Measures/Detail.aspx?id=1302602&session=2007
--Apple-Mail-7-987319326
Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset=US-ASCII;
	format=flowed;
	delsp=yes
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit



So, the nice thing is, the site provided said data in tab-delimited  
spreadsheet format; suitable for import into OpenOffice, Google Docs,  
excel, or any other spreadsheet of your choice. I've taken the liberty  
of fetching the data already available, sorting by state, city, then  
employer; and bundling it up into a megaupload:

http://www.megaupload.com/?d=FBDGNQ9V
--Apple-Mail-7-987319326
Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset=US-ASCII;
	format=flowed;
	delsp=yes
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit



First off... one important note: Not all of the PACs which pushed prop  
8 have properly submitted their data to the Secretary of State yet. So  
it is important to keep checking back at the site to get the updated  
data as it comes in.

Note that I sorted by employer. Yes, in most cases, the data includes  
the employers. So let's bring these bastards out into the spotlight.  
Find the business on the list in your area, boycott them; but most  
importantly: CONTACT THEM, let them know WHY you are boycotting, and  
what they can do to rectify the situation. There are some pretty juicy  
names in the employer column; some of whom are already fairly well- 
known to have strong anti-discrimination policies... boycott or no.

 From there, the possibilities are only limited by the imagination.  
The data is easily cross-referenced into whitepages.com or similar,  
for example; so the opportunity is there to fight back and drive the  
message home on a more personal level. (Heck... turns out  
whitepages.com has an API available so the process could be automated.  
But the data is fairly easy to manipulate, no matter what you wish to  
do. (For example, simply sort by employer and go after the ones with  
the largest infestations of bigots; wether they are local and boycott- 
able or not. Bad PR can count for a lot with some of these outfits.)

Myself, I'm going through the lists, looking for more likely 501(c)3  
candidates to file IRS form 13909's against.

Let's not stop now. Let's strike back, and hard. Marching on City Hall  
or into the Castro may be fun and all; but it basically amounts to  
"preaching to the choir". Here's a chance to hit the actual enemy back  
where it'll stand a chance of hurting them.


cya,
john

From: John B <svnlyrbrto@gmail.com>
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] NRR: More ways to fight back against the prop 8 bigots... 

--Apple-Mail-9-988297384
Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset=US-ASCII;
	format=flowed;
	delsp=yes
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

As part of campaign finance disclosure and transparency, the  
California Secretary of State's website provides the donor lists to  
the various yes on 8 PACs:

http://cal-access.ss.ca.gov/Campaign/Measures/Detail.aspx?id=1302602&session=2007

So, the nice thing is, the site provided said data in tab-delimited  
spreadsheet format; suitable for import into OpenOffice, Google Docs,  
excel, or any other spreadsheet of your choice. I've taken the liberty  
of fetching the data already available, sorting by state, city, then  
employer; and bundling it up into a megaupload:

http://www.megaupload.com/?d=FBDGNQ9V

First off... one important note: Not all of the PACs which pushed prop  
8 have properly submitted their data to the Secretary of State yet. So  
it is important to keep checking back at the site to get the updated  
data as it comes in.

Note that I sorted by employer. Yes, in most cases, the data includes  
the employers. So let's bring these bastards out into the spotlight.  
Find the business on the list in your area, boycott them; but most  
importantly: CONTACT THEM, let them know WHY you are boycotting, and  
what they can do to rectify the situation. There are some pretty juicy  
names in the employer column; some of whom are already fairly well- 
known to have strong anti-discrimination policies... boycott or no.

 From there, the possibilities are only limited by the imagination.  
The data is easily cross-referenced into whitepages.com or similar,  
for example; so the opportunity is there to fight back and drive the  
message home on a more personal level. (Heck... turns out  
whitepages.com has an API available so the process could be automated.  
But the data is fairly easy to manipulate, no matter what you wish to  
do. (For example, simply sort by employer and go after the ones with  
the largest infestations of bigots; wether they are local and boycott- 
able or not. Bad PR can count for a lot with some of these outfits.)

Myself, I'm going through the lists, looking for more likely 501(c)3  
candidates to file IRS form 13909's against.

Let's not stop now. Let's strike back, and hard. Marching on City Hall  
or into the Castro may be fun and all; but it basically amounts to  
"preaching to the choir". Here's a chance to hit the actual enemy back  
where it'll stand a chance of hurting them.


cya,
john

largest infestations of bigots; wether they are local and boycott-able =
or not. Bad PR can count for a lot with some of these =
outfits.)<br><br>Myself, I'm going through the lists, looking for more =
likely 501(c)3 candidates to file IRS form 13909's against.<br><br>Let's =
not stop now. Let's strike back, and hard. Marching on City Hall or into =
the Castro may be fun and all; but it basically amounts to "preaching to =
the choir". Here's a chance to hit the actual enemy back where it'll =
stand a chance of hurting =
them.<br><br><br>cya,<br>john<br></body></html>=

Subject: [sfraves] The f-word (was Re: [sfraves] Goodbye)

You know, Alex, it is a choice to use words that offend people.  You can chose not to use these words.

However, it is also a choice to be offended by a word that someone else uses. One can also choose not to be offended.

One of things about the gay community I've always respected was the way
they appropriated the pink triangle for themselves. The pink triangle was used by the Nazis (Godwin Alert)  to
identify homosexuals for incarcerations and subsequent elimination.  
In spite of this, the gay community has taken this symbol for
themselves; some might know about the giant triangle that is displayed
during pride week.  Can you imagine the Jewish community self
identifying with the Nazi's yellow star?  I can't.

I served on a jury a few months back, and I remember the defense
attorneys taking the time to explain the difference between the n-word
ending in -er and ending in -ah.  Only it was bullshit.  They are the
same exact word, the difference seems to be that the word is used by
different people in different contexts.

Most of my gay friends self identify with the f-word.  My good friend
Jesse actually calls hims self an "old f-word" most frequently,
although sometimes he uses the q-word as well.  He would probably laugh
at a gay person who was offended I think.  And of course Shatter pointed out the well known Friday night parties that graced the End Up for many many years. I don't recall anyone protesting or complaining, but maybe someone did.

I know a lot of us including myself are grateful to Apollo for all of the wisdom he's shared over the years, the parties hes thrown, and so on.  He's an inspiration to many of us on this list.  Apollo I don't agreee with you at all on this issue, but I wish you hte best and thank you for everything you've given of yourself.  I understand your decision and you will be sorely missed.  

In my biew, we shouldn't let any word control us, and if you are offended by the n-word, the f-word , the-c-word, or any other word you are allowing yourself to be controlled by the people that use those words.  Take back the words and you are free.  

Think about it.

Best,

Peter

I was in Dresden, Germany yesterday, to visit my grandfather's grave, among
other things and as I was walking thru town yesterday I noticed crews
setting up sound and light equipment throughout the entire city.

Turns out the entire town threw itself a massive party, without any of the
bullshit frisson that comes from it being treated as an underground, illici=
t
activity like it is here in the States.

The front of my hotel was used as the background for a huge laser light sho=
w
that went on until dawn, in the middle of a high end, hoighty toighty, Unio=
n
Square type shopping district.

Let me repeat that...

There. Was. A. Rave: That. Went. On. All. Night. In. Front. Of. My. Hotel.
In. Germany.

One DJ, with a Burberry record bag, was spinning -*inside*- a motherfucking
McDonald's, (btw, The Royale with Cheese story from Pulp Fiction because
they don't have quarter pounders since there is no metric system and ppl
wouldn't understand that, and you can get beer in McDonalds just happens to
be true), and on top of that management let him put a spinning disco ball i=
n
the window during his set, (will post video when I get back home), bet it'l=
l
be a cold day in hell that you ll ever see that happen on Market or Van Nes=
s
street, but I wouldn t hold my bre=E4th waiting 4 that p=F6ssibility.

Also, the drinking age is 18 there and people are allowed to drink in
public, out of bottles that don t need a paper bag to hide them, and real E
goes for 15 bux, American, for a hit.

Yet, with all that, there was none of the feral energy associated with an
all ages event that Im used to and in the whole time I was out in a crowd
that was easily 20 thousand plus people I only saw 2 cops.

So, in light of this set of eye opening experiences I'd say that 'rave' is
dead in the USA, and gone as far as it prolly ever will for the forseeable
future and while it is a little alarming to see you go, =C4p=F6ll=F6, since=
 for
many of us you were the first person that stood out in this crowd here in
SFR; I can see why you feel that way, since I've been trending in that
direction myself for a while now.

Maybe we'll meet again further on up the road, and even if we don't, much
love to you and Joey and may you get everything you want out of life,
starting with your physical health, and shit.

Peace, Love Unity and Mad Respect,

Nyc

---

"You can chose not to use these words."

If people are still offended by things that I'm saying my work isn't done
here.

:-)

On Sun, Nov 9, 2008 at 2:41 PM, <dangrsmind@yahoo.com> wrote:

> You know, Alex, it is a choice to use words that offend people.  You can
> chose not to use these words.
>
> However, it is also a choice to be offended by a word that someone else
> uses. One can also choose not to be offended.
>
> One of things about the gay community I've always respected was the way
> they appropriated the pink triangle for themselves. The pink triangle was
> used by the Nazis (Godwin Alert)  to
> identify homosexuals for incarcerations and subsequent elimination.
> In spite of this, the gay community has taken this symbol for
> themselves; some might know about the giant triangle that is displayed
> during pride week.  Can you imagine the Jewish community self
> identifying with the Nazi's yellow star?  I can't.
>
> I served on a jury a few months back, and I remember the defense
> attorneys taking the time to explain the difference between the n-word
> ending in -er and ending in -ah.  Only it was bullshit.  They are the
> same exact word, the difference seems to be that the word is used by
> different people in different contexts.
>
> Most of my gay friends self identify with the f-word.  My good friend
> Jesse actually calls hims self an "old f-word" most frequently,
> although sometimes he uses the q-word as well.  He would probably laugh
> at a gay person who was offended I think.  And of course Shatter pointed
> out the well known Friday night parties that graced the End Up for many many
> years. I don't recall anyone protesting or complaining, but maybe someone
> did.
>
> I know a lot of us including myself are grateful to Apollo for all of the
> wisdom he's shared over the years, the parties hes thrown, and so on.  He's
> an inspiration to many of us on this list.  Apollo I don't agreee with you
> at all on this issue, but I wish you hte best and thank you for everything
> you've given of yourself.  I understand your decision and you will be sorely
> missed.
>
> In my biew, we shouldn't let any word control us, and if you are offended
> by the n-word, the f-word , the-c-word, or any other word you are allowing
> yourself to be controlled by the people that use those words.  Take back the
> words and you are free.
>
> Think about it.
>
> Best,
>
> Peter
>
>
>
>
> ----- Original Message ----
> From: Apollo <djapollo2k@mac.com>
> To: SFRaves@hyperreal.org
> Sent: Sunday, November 9, 2008 1:22:01 PM
> Subject: [sfraves] Goodbye
>
> You know, folks, I've been on this list off and on (mainly on) since the
> beginning.  This last run has lasted about ten years and I'm thinking that's
> enough.  Most of my close friends are gone from the list and of those that
> remain, well, I can keep in contact with them on other more pleasant venues.
>
> Much love,
>
> Apollo
>
>
>
> Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org
>
> House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm
>
> The US is:  "...a nation of 200 million used-car salesmen with all the
> money we need to buy guns and no qualms about killing anybody else in the
> world who tries to make us uncomfortable."
> -Hunter S. Thompson
>
> "Friend, hope for the truth while you are alive.  Jump into experience
> while you are alive!  What you call "salvation" belongs to the time before
> death.  If you don't break your ropes while you are alive, do you think
> ghosts will do it after?"
> -Kabir
>

John B wrote:
> As part of campaign finance disclosure and transparency, the
> California Secretary of State's website provides the donor lists to
> the various yes on 8 PACs:
>
> http://cal-access.ss.ca.gov/Campaign/Measures/Detail.aspx?id=1302602&session=2007
>
>
> So, the nice thing is, the site provided said data in tab-delimited
> spreadsheet format; suitable for import into OpenOffice, Google Docs,
> excel, or any other spreadsheet of your choice. I've taken the liberty
> of fetching the data already available, sorting by state, city, then
> employer; and bundling it up into a megaupload:
>
> http://www.megaupload.com/?d=FBDGNQ9V
>
>
> First off... one important note: Not all of the PACs which pushed prop
> 8 have properly submitted their data to the Secretary of State yet. So
> it is important to keep checking back at the site to get the updated
> data as it comes in.
>
> Note that I sorted by employer. Yes, in most cases, the data includes
> the employers. So let's bring these bastards out into the spotlight.
> Find the business on the list in your area, boycott them; but most
> importantly: CONTACT THEM, let them know WHY you are boycotting, and
> what they can do to rectify the situation. There are some pretty juicy
> names in the employer column; some of whom are already fairly
> well-known to have strong anti-discrimination policies... boycott or no.
>
> From there, the possibilities are only limited by the imagination. The
> data is easily cross-referenced into whitepages.com or similar, for
> example; so the opportunity is there to fight back and drive the
> message home on a more personal level. (Heck... turns out
> whitepages.com has an API available so the process could be automated.
> But the data is fairly easy to manipulate, no matter what you wish to
> do. (For example, simply sort by employer and go after the ones with
> the largest infestations of bigots; wether they are local and
> boycott-able or not. Bad PR can count for a lot with some of these
> outfits.)
>
> Myself, I'm going through the lists, looking for more likely 501(c)3
> candidates to file IRS form 13909's against.
>
> Let's not stop now. Let's strike back, and hard. Marching on City Hall
> or into the Castro may be fun and all; but it basically amounts to
> "preaching to the choir". Here's a chance to hit the actual enemy back
> where it'll stand a chance of hurting them.
>
>
> cya,
> john

Subject: Re: [sfraves] The f-word (was Re: [sfraves] Goodbye)

PORCH MONKEY 4 LIFE!

I'm taking it back!

(if you haven't seen Clerks 2, please don't be offended)

-----------------------------

I have a soft spot for offensive words.  I don't feel ANY word should be
verbotten.  There is a proper time and place for all words.  The more
offensive, the better, because there are times it's the only thing to
shock people out of their stupor.  Over use can diminish the word
though.  South park did a fine example of this with Night of 1000
Shits.  By #120 you sorta don't even notice or care anymore, but teh
first 10-15 were funny as hell.  Hateful words can be turned around to
show how utterly stupid peopel are for using them.  I mean, common, far
better ways to insult somebody other than genetics.  Linage is a far
better one...  ;)

At Endup with Fag Fridays there were MANY times I got to use the club
name in some creative uses.  Everyone one of the times it was directed
at uptight straight people who were shocked on everyones behalf,
typically to the laughter of the crowd hanging around.  Typically
something along the lines of "Well, it's call FAG FRIDAY...  you tell me
if you think it's a Gay Club." At which point they would start in with
something like "DO I LOOK GAY?" (best question ever) to which i would
usually respond with any number of "Well I don't want to fuck you,l so I
don't really care if you are or not" or "I have no idea what GAY looks
like" or "I don't know, go in and dance with all the shirtless guys and
let me know how it works out for you....   unless you're HOMOPHOBIC" 
Good times.  At one of the anniversaries a great moment of taking the
hate and making it endearment was David Harness on the mic say "Hello! 
Any Fags in this party tonight?" and in response a unified cheering
applause with massive whoops and yells. 

On the other hand, I have turned away, and will always as long as I work
there continue to turn away anyone who for a split second suggests they
may have a problem with Gay/Black/Asian/White, etc.  I will not abide by
hate.  When asked these days if it's a Gay Club I say "It's an everybody
club.  I'm not checking peoples gay cards, just their legal ID.  Gay,
Straight, Bi, Transgender, we get everyone here, and everyone is
welcome, unless you're an asshole.

One of my gay card references got a couple of customers laughing who
said "OMG, we should TOTALLY make GAY CARDS for people to carry
around!!!"  If anyone does though it should list their hanky code on it.

I hear Nigger/Nigga (see, made you gasp!) at least 20x a shift.  It's
always used funny or as an endearment, and yes, by the black guys I work
with.  A few weeks ago an asshole called the guy on door that and
threatened to kill him for not letting him back in after getting kicked
out.  Yelled it out his car window driving by (real brave). We could
have gotten aggro but instead I looked at JB and said "Holy shit.... 
you're black??"  "On radio "Hey guys!!  Did you know the JB was black?" 
JB retorted "I am as shocked as the rest of you to find this out."

Then again, I'll flare up like pack of hemorrhoids with hate speech
anywhere near the club.  It's inappropriate and uncalled for.  People
slinging it at another to cause hurt have no business being there.  They
are ejected with extreme prejudice.

The irony with ALL of the hateful words, is not one single one is
considered bad form, or even offensive to say about white people.  Not
starting an argument or debate on this, just pointing this out as a
"Hmmmm......"

--S

Well, it's nearly 10AM in Washington DC.  I'm in Santa Cruz, though, I =20
just wanted to remind everyone of the time zones.

I want to start off by making a comment to perhaps the most shocking =20
post I saw this weekend with Peter telling Apollo that he can choose =20
whether or not to get offended by someone else using the 'f' word or =20
the 'n' word.  Wow, he is so open minded and progressive, it's amazing =20
he thinks other people should just look the other way or turn the =20
other cheek when they read something that pisses them off, yet the =20
second he reads something not even directed at him that he doesn't =20
like, he turns into a howling witch hunter urging everyone not to read =20
my posts.  I've got another word for you, Peter, that is the 'h' word. =20
  Hypocrite.  Everybody's got their boiling point, dude.  Why don't =20
you try stepping out of your own reality and realize you have not been =20
through what Apollo and others have been through.

I'll have you know that Terry's silence on any of my posts and someone =20
like Philip who makes one comment he doesn't really appreciate hearing =20
about conspiracy theories 24 hours a day weighs a hell of a lot more =20
heavily on my decision of what to post than anything you've ever had =20
to say.  So hopefully you'll think about that, and know that I am =20
fully aware there is another person on the other side of this =20
keyboard, but you should know that if we ever meet in person, this =20
subject I am writing about now will be the first topic I bring up to =20
you.  No delay.

OK here is what we now all have to deal with once everyone has sent =20
out their complaint letters to the IRS ratting out churches.  We've =20
got 71 days until Shatter and others, actually everyone, I mean =20
everyone ships off to compuslory national service.  And when I say =20
everyone, if you don't think I'm going to drive up to Treasure Island =20
and make sure Shatter gets on the bus, too, you've got another think =20
coming.

Just kidding, Shatter.  Just look at the bright side.  Record gun =20
sales, and from what I see, everyone is freaking out right now.  This =20
might be a good thing.

I'm putting together a website as part of a school project, yes, I'm =20
taking some web design classes, to go over approximately 9 steps that =20
I think people need to mobilize against facism.  It's coming to =20
America, unfortunately the people that Obama is the new messiah might =20
be the last people to realize it.  I'll credit Webster Tarpley for =20
this list, but yesterday I spent the entire day writing a rough draft =20
for the content.  If someone has a catchier name phrase than a united =20
front against facism, please feel free to come forward.  Remember that =20
raves won't be very fun if we have to run around with a geiger counter.

Here is the rough outline of the drafts:

--

1.  No honeymoon for the coporate facist state.

2.  No to censorship based on the Fairness Doctrine or any type of =20
hate speech legislation.

3.  No to voluntary service.

4.  No to cap and trade taxes based on the idea of fighting 'global =20
warming'.  Man made global warming is a myth created by the corporate =20
facist state.

5.  No to free-trade sell-outs.  We've seen what NAFTA and other laws =20
that encourage companies to move their operations offshore or to use =20
cheap prison labor to get their job done.

6.  No to the looting of Social Security.  Clinton did this in the =20
90's to balance the budget, and Kramer on CNBC is now calling for =20
looting Social Security to pay off bad debts.  No.

7.  No to war with Russia.  No to the Polish Missle Crisis.  If Mr. =20
Obama is truly the Messiah, let him stand down from provoking war with =20
a giant like Russia.

8.  No to war with Pakistan.

9.  Get the troops out of Iraq and Afghanistan.

Remember, get active, or get radioactive!

We live in a country where instead of celebrating that a 40+ year old woman
looking good enough to show off her healthy body, we lose our shit on a
national level when Janet Jackson nearly flashes a tit on live TV.

And it's been years since George Carlin first did his 7 dirty words bit, and
he up and died before that one got changed, as a matter of fact the US
Supreme Court said you can't do that, still:
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/F.C.C._v._Pacifica_Foundation

Doubt that that's gonna get overturned anytime soon.

Unless of course, you're Joe Scarborough
http://wonkette.com/404267/joe-scarborough-says-f-word-on-live-television


There's a an art to using shock words for effect which is lost on FM radio
morning zoo types.

The other night some Neo Nazi skinhead I was talking with at a party I was
at, on the 70th Anniversary of Kristal Nacht, no less, called Obama the N
word, and I shot back, in German, with,

'Yeah, he's a n****r alright, that's true, but at least, unlike your Herr
Hitller, at least he's a WINNER and not a whilte skinned LOSER that had to
shoot his White brains out, right?'

Fucking idiot was so pissed, and speechless, that the only thing he and his
friends could do was throw down on me, (you should have seen their eyes do
pinwheels, in real life it looks just the same as it does in cartooons),
they but I just laughed at them and wished them a good evening as I walked
off.

But anywayz America at its core is a Puritan country, (with the emotional
maturity of a 15 year old, which is why fart\dick jokes are big here and
Adam Sandler still gets $20 million a picture), and it's never going to
change, and the battle of words you're engaged in is prolly a losing one,
but feel free to try.

Sign me your loyal and faithful translucent honky ass cracker trailer trash
motherfucker.

....

On Mon, Nov 10, 2008 at 8:41 AM, Shatter <shatter@sonic.net> wrote:

> PORCH MONKEY 4 LIFE!
>
> I'm taking it back!
>
> (if you haven't seen Clerks 2, please don't be offended)
>
> -----------------------------
>
> I have a soft spot for offensive words.  I don't feel ANY word should be
> verbotten.  There is a proper time and place for all words.  The more
> offensive, the better, because there are times it's the only thing to
> shock people out of their stupor.  Over use can diminish the word
> though.  South park did a fine example of this with Night of 1000
> Shits.  By #120 you sorta don't even notice or care anymore, but teh
> first 10-15 were funny as hell.  Hateful words can be turned around to
> show how utterly stupid peopel are for using them.  I mean, common, far
> better ways to insult somebody other than genetics.  Linage is a far
> better one...  ;)
>
> At Endup with Fag Fridays there were MANY times I got to use the club
> name in some creative uses.  Everyone one of the times it was directed
> at uptight straight people who were shocked on everyones behalf,
> typically to the laughter of the crowd hanging around.  Typically
> something along the lines of "Well, it's call FAG FRIDAY...  you tell me
> if you think it's a Gay Club." At which point they would start in with
> something like "DO I LOOK GAY?" (best question ever) to which i would
> usually respond with any number of "Well I don't want to fuck you,l so I
> don't really care if you are or not" or "I have no idea what GAY looks
> like" or "I don't know, go in and dance with all the shirtless guys and
> let me know how it works out for you....   unless you're HOMOPHOBIC"
> Good times.  At one of the anniversaries a great moment of taking the
> hate and making it endearment was David Harness on the mic say "Hello!
> Any Fags in this party tonight?" and in response a unified cheering
> applause with massive whoops and yells.
>
> On the other hand, I have turned away, and will always as long as I work
> there continue to turn away anyone who for a split second suggests they
> may have a problem with Gay/Black/Asian/White, etc.  I will not abide by
> hate.  When asked these days if it's a Gay Club I say "It's an everybody
> club.  I'm not checking peoples gay cards, just their legal ID.  Gay,
> Straight, Bi, Transgender, we get everyone here, and everyone is
> welcome, unless you're an asshole.
>
> One of my gay card references got a couple of customers laughing who
> said "OMG, we should TOTALLY make GAY CARDS for people to carry
> around!!!"  If anyone does though it should list their hanky code on it.
>
> I hear Nigger/Nigga (see, made you gasp!) at least 20x a shift.  It's
> always used funny or as an endearment, and yes, by the black guys I work
> with.  A few weeks ago an asshole called the guy on door that and
> threatened to kill him for not letting him back in after getting kicked
> out.  Yelled it out his car window driving by (real brave). We could
> have gotten aggro but instead I looked at JB and said "Holy shit....
> you're black??"  "On radio "Hey guys!!  Did you know the JB was black?"
> JB retorted "I am as shocked as the rest of you to find this out."
>
> Then again, I'll flare up like pack of hemorrhoids with hate speech
> anywhere near the club.  It's inappropriate and uncalled for.  People
> slinging it at another to cause hurt have no business being there.  They
> are ejected with extreme prejudice.
>
> The irony with ALL of the hateful words, is not one single one is
> considered bad form, or even offensive to say about white people.  Not
> starting an argument or debate on this, just pointing this out as a
> "Hmmmm......"
>
> --S
>
> dangrsmind@yahoo.com wrote:
> > You know, Alex, it is a choice to use words that offend people.  You can
> chose not to use these words.
> >
> > However, it is also a choice to be offended by a word that someone else
> uses. One can also choose not to be offended.
> >
> > One of things about the gay community I've always respected was the way
> > they appropriated the pink triangle for themselves. The pink triangle was
> used by the Nazis (Godwin Alert)  to
> > identify homosexuals for incarcerations and subsequent elimination.
> > In spite of this, the gay community has taken this symbol for
> > themselves; some might know about the giant triangle that is displayed
> > during pride week.  Can you imagine the Jewish community self
> > identifying with the Nazi's yellow star?  I can't.
> >
> > I served on a jury a few months back, and I remember the defense
> > attorneys taking the time to explain the difference between the n-word
> > ending in -er and ending in -ah.  Only it was bullshit.  They are the
> > same exact word, the difference seems to be that the word is used by
> > different people in different contexts.
> >
> > Most of my gay friends self identify with the f-word.  My good friend
> > Jesse actually calls hims self an "old f-word" most frequently,
> > although sometimes he uses the q-word as well.  He would probably laugh
> > at a gay person who was offended I think.  And of course Shatter pointed
> out the well known Friday night parties that graced the End Up for many many
> years. I don't recall anyone protesting or complaining, but maybe someone
> did.
> >
> > I know a lot of us including myself are grateful to Apollo for all of the

What do you call an elevator filled with white people?

. . .

A box of crackers!

On Mon, Nov 10, 2008 at 4:13 PM, Nyc Labrets <digitalcomponents@gmail.com>wrote:

> We live in a country where instead of celebrating that a 40+ year old woman
> looking good enough to show off her healthy body, we lose our shit on a
> national level when Janet Jackson nearly flashes a tit on live TV.
>
> And it's been years since George Carlin first did his 7 dirty words bit,
> and
> he up and died before that one got changed, as a matter of fact the US
> Supreme Court said you can't do that, still:
> http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/F.C.C._v._Pacifica_Foundation
>
> Doubt that that's gonna get overturned anytime soon.
>
> Unless of course, you're Joe Scarborough
> http://wonkette.com/404267/joe-scarborough-says-f-word-on-live-television
>
>
> There's a an art to using shock words for effect which is lost on FM radio
> morning zoo types.
>
> The other night some Neo Nazi skinhead I was talking with at a party I was
> at, on the 70th Anniversary of Kristal Nacht, no less, called Obama the N
> word, and I shot back, in German, with,
>
> 'Yeah, he's a n****r alright, that's true, but at least, unlike your Herr
> Hitller, at least he's a WINNER and not a whilte skinned LOSER that had to
> shoot his White brains out, right?'
>
> Fucking idiot was so pissed, and speechless, that the only thing he and his
> friends could do was throw down on me, (you should have seen their eyes do
> pinwheels, in real life it looks just the same as it does in cartooons),
> they but I just laughed at them and wished them a good evening as I walked
> off.
>
> But anywayz America at its core is a Puritan country, (with the emotional
> maturity of a 15 year old, which is why fart\dick jokes are big here and
> Adam Sandler still gets $20 million a picture), and it's never going to
> change, and the battle of words you're engaged in is prolly a losing one,
> but feel free to try.
>
> Sign me your loyal and faithful translucent honky ass cracker trailer trash
> motherfucker.
>
> ....
>
> On Mon, Nov 10, 2008 at 8:41 AM, Shatter <shatter@sonic.net> wrote:
>
> > PORCH MONKEY 4 LIFE!
> >
> > I'm taking it back!
> >
> > (if you haven't seen Clerks 2, please don't be offended)
> >
> > -----------------------------
> >
> > I have a soft spot for offensive words.  I don't feel ANY word should be
> > verbotten.  There is a proper time and place for all words.  The more
> > offensive, the better, because there are times it's the only thing to
> > shock people out of their stupor.  Over use can diminish the word
> > though.  South park did a fine example of this with Night of 1000
> > Shits.  By #120 you sorta don't even notice or care anymore, but teh
> > first 10-15 were funny as hell.  Hateful words can be turned around to
> > show how utterly stupid peopel are for using them.  I mean, common, far
> > better ways to insult somebody other than genetics.  Linage is a far
> > better one...  ;)
> >
> > At Endup with Fag Fridays there were MANY times I got to use the club
> > name in some creative uses.  Everyone one of the times it was directed
> > at uptight straight people who were shocked on everyones behalf,
> > typically to the laughter of the crowd hanging around.  Typically
> > something along the lines of "Well, it's call FAG FRIDAY...  you tell me
> > if you think it's a Gay Club." At which point they would start in with
> > something like "DO I LOOK GAY?" (best question ever) to which i would
> > usually respond with any number of "Well I don't want to fuck you,l so I
> > don't really care if you are or not" or "I have no idea what GAY looks
> > like" or "I don't know, go in and dance with all the shirtless guys and
> > let me know how it works out for you....   unless you're HOMOPHOBIC"
> > Good times.  At one of the anniversaries a great moment of taking the
> > hate and making it endearment was David Harness on the mic say "Hello!
> > Any Fags in this party tonight?" and in response a unified cheering
> > applause with massive whoops and yells.
> >
> > On the other hand, I have turned away, and will always as long as I work
> > there continue to turn away anyone who for a split second suggests they
> > may have a problem with Gay/Black/Asian/White, etc.  I will not abide by
> > hate.  When asked these days if it's a Gay Club I say "It's an everybody
> > club.  I'm not checking peoples gay cards, just their legal ID.  Gay,
> > Straight, Bi, Transgender, we get everyone here, and everyone is
> > welcome, unless you're an asshole.
> >
> > One of my gay card references got a couple of customers laughing who
> > said "OMG, we should TOTALLY make GAY CARDS for people to carry
> > around!!!"  If anyone does though it should list their hanky code on it.
> >
> > I hear Nigger/Nigga (see, made you gasp!) at least 20x a shift.  It's
> > always used funny or as an endearment, and yes, by the black guys I work
> > with.  A few weeks ago an asshole called the guy on door that and
> > threatened to kill him for not letting him back in after getting kicked
> > out.  Yelled it out his car window driving by (real brave). We could
> > have gotten aggro but instead I looked at JB and said "Holy shit....
> > you're black??"  "On radio "Hey guys!!  Did you know the JB was black?"
> > JB retorted "I am as shocked as the rest of you to find this out."
> >
> > Then again, I'll flare up like pack of hemorrhoids with hate speech
> > anywhere near the club.  It's inappropriate and uncalled for.  People
> > slinging it at another to cause hurt have no business being there.  They
> > are ejected with extreme prejudice.
> >
> > The irony with ALL of the hateful words, is not one single one is
> > considered bad form, or even offensive to say about white people.  Not
> > starting an argument or debate on this, just pointing this out as a
> > "Hmmmm......"
> >
> > --S
> >
> > dangrsmind@yahoo.com wrote:
> > > You know, Alex, it is a choice to use words that offend people.  You
> can
> > chose not to use these words.
> > >
> > > However, it is also a choice to be offended by a word that someone else
> > uses. One can also choose not to be offended.
> > >
> > > One of things about the gay community I've always respected was the way
> > > they appropriated the pink triangle for themselves. The pink triangle
> was
> > used by the Nazis (Godwin Alert)  to
> > > identify homosexuals for incarcerations and subsequent elimination.
> > > In spite of this, the gay community has taken this symbol for
> > > themselves; some might know about the giant triangle that is displayed
> > > during pride week.  Can you imagine the Jewish community self
> > > identifying with the Nazi's yellow star?  I can't.
> > >
> > > I served on a jury a few months back, and I remember the defense
> > > attorneys taking the time to explain the difference between the n-word
> > > ending in -er and ending in -ah.  Only it was bullshit.  They are the
> > > same exact word, the difference seems to be that the word is used by
> > > different people in different contexts.
> > >
> > > Most of my gay friends self identify with the f-word.  My good friend
> > > Jesse actually calls hims self an "old f-word" most frequently,
> > > although sometimes he uses the q-word as well.  He would probably laugh
> > > at a gay person who was offended I think.  And of course Shatter
> pointed
> > out the well known Friday night parties that graced the End Up for many
> many
> > years. I don't recall anyone protesting or complaining, but maybe someone
> > did.
> > >
> > > I know a lot of us including myself are grateful to Apollo for all of
> the
> > wisdom he's shared over the years, the parties hes thrown, and so on.
>  He's
> > an inspiration to many of us on this list.  Apollo I don't agreee with
> you
> > at all on this issue, but I wish you hte best and thank you for
> everything
> > you've given of yourself.  I understand your decision and you will be
> sorely
> > missed.
> > >
> > > In my biew, we shouldn't let any word control us, and if you are
> offended
> > by the n-word, the f-word , the-c-word, or any other word you are
> allowing
> > yourself to be controlled by the people that use those words.  Take back
> the
> > words and you are free.
> > >
> > > Think about it.
> > >
> > > Best,
> > >
> > > Peter
> > >
> > >
> > >
> > >

> > >
> > > One of things about the gay community I've always respected was the way
> > > they appropriated the pink triangle for themselves. The pink triangle
> was
> > used by the Nazis (Godwin Alert)  to
> > > identify homosexuals for incarcerations and subsequent elimination.
> > > In spite of this, the gay community has taken this symbol for
> > > themselves; some might know about the giant triangle that is displayed
> > > during pride week.  Can you imagine the Jewish community self
> > > identifying with the Nazi's yellow star?  I can't.
> > >
> > > I served on a jury a few months back, and I remember the defense
> > > attorneys taking the time to explain the difference between the n-word
> > > ending in -er and ending in -ah.  Only it was bullshit.  They are the
> > > same exact word, the difference seems to be that the word is used by
> > > different people in different contexts.
> > >
> > > Most of my gay friends self identify with the f-word.  My good friend
> > > Jesse actually calls hims self an "old f-word" most frequently,
> > > although sometimes he uses the q-word as well.  He would probably laugh
> > > at a gay person who was offended I think.  And of course Shatter
> pointed
> > out the well known Friday night parties that graced the End Up for many
> many
> > years. I don't recall anyone protesting or complaining, but maybe someone
> > did.
> > >
> > > I know a lot of us including myself are grateful to Apollo for all of
> the
> > wisdom he's shared over the years, the parties hes thrown, and so on.
>  He's
> > an inspiration to many of us on this list.  Apollo I don't agreee with
> you
> > at all on this issue, but I wish you hte best and thank you for
> everything
> > you've given of yourself.  I understand your decision and you will be
> sorely
> > missed.
> > >
> > > In my biew, we shouldn't let any word control us, and if you are
> offended
> > by the n-word, the f-word , the-c-word, or any other word you are
> allowing
> > yourself to be controlled by the people that use those words.  Take back
> the
> > words and you are free.
> > >
> > > Think about it.
> > >
> > > Best,
> > >
> > > Peter
> > >
> > >
> > >
> > >

On Mon, Nov 10, 2008 at 4:13 PM, Nyc Labrets <digitalcomponents@gmail.com>wrote:

> We live in a country where instead of celebrating that a 40+ year old woman
> looking good enough to show off her healthy body, we lose our shit on a
> national level when Janet Jackson nearly flashes a tit on live TV.
>
> And it's been years since George Carlin first did his 7 dirty words bit,
> and
> he up and died before that one got changed, as a matter of fact the US
> Supreme Court said you can't do that, still:
> http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/F.C.C._v._Pacifica_Foundation
>
> Doubt that that's gonna get overturned anytime soon.
>
> Unless of course, you're Joe Scarborough
> http://wonkette.com/404267/joe-scarborough-says-f-word-on-live-television
>
>
> There's a an art to using shock words for effect which is lost on FM radio
> morning zoo types.
>
> The other night some Neo Nazi skinhead I was talking with at a party I was
> at, on the 70th Anniversary of Kristal Nacht, no less, called Obama the N
> word, and I shot back, in German, with,
>
> 'Yeah, he's a n****r alright, that's true, but at least, unlike your Herr
> Hitller, at least he's a WINNER and not a whilte skinned LOSER that had to
> shoot his White brains out, right?'
>
> Fucking idiot was so pissed, and speechless, that the only thing he and his
> friends could do was throw down on me, (you should have seen their eyes do
> pinwheels, in real life it looks just the same as it does in cartooons),
> they but I just laughed at them and wished them a good evening as I walked
> off.
>
> But anywayz America at its core is a Puritan country, (with the emotional
> maturity of a 15 year old, which is why fart\dick jokes are big here and
> Adam Sandler still gets $20 million a picture), and it's never going to
> change, and the battle of words you're engaged in is prolly a losing one,
> but feel free to try.
>
> Sign me your loyal and faithful translucent honky ass cracker trailer trash
> motherfucker.
>
> ....
>
> On Mon, Nov 10, 2008 at 8:41 AM, Shatter <shatter@sonic.net> wrote:
>
> > PORCH MONKEY 4 LIFE!
> >
> > I'm taking it back!
> >
> > (if you haven't seen Clerks 2, please don't be offended)
> >
> > -----------------------------
> >
> > I have a soft spot for offensive words.  I don't feel ANY word should be
> > verbotten.  There is a proper time and place for all words.  The more
> > offensive, the better, because there are times it's the only thing to
> > shock people out of their stupor.  Over use can diminish the word
> > though.  South park did a fine example of this with Night of 1000
> > Shits.  By #120 you sorta don't even notice or care anymore, but teh
> > first 10-15 were funny as hell.  Hateful words can be turned around to
> > show how utterly stupid peopel are for using them.  I mean, common, far
> > better ways to insult somebody other than genetics.  Linage is a far
> > better one...  ;)
> >
> > At Endup with Fag Fridays there were MANY times I got to use the club
> > name in some creative uses.  Everyone one of the times it was directed
> > at uptight straight people who were shocked on everyones behalf,
> > typically to the laughter of the crowd hanging around.  Typically
> > something along the lines of "Well, it's call FAG FRIDAY...  you tell me
> > if you think it's a Gay Club." At which point they would start in with
> > something like "DO I LOOK GAY?" (best question ever) to which i would
> > usually respond with any number of "Well I don't want to fuck you,l so I
> > don't really care if you are or not" or "I have no idea what GAY looks
> > like" or "I don't know, go in and dance with all the shirtless guys and
> > let me know how it works out for you....   unless you're HOMOPHOBIC"
> > Good times.  At one of the anniversaries a great moment of taking the
> > hate and making it endearment was David Harness on the mic say "Hello!
> > Any Fags in this party tonight?" and in response a unified cheering
> > applause with massive whoops and yells.
> >
> > On the other hand, I have turned away, and will always as long as I work
> > there continue to turn away anyone who for a split second suggests they
> > may have a problem with Gay/Black/Asian/White, etc.  I will not abide by
> > hate.  When asked these days if it's a Gay Club I say "It's an everybody
> > club.  I'm not checking peoples gay cards, just their legal ID.  Gay,
> > Straight, Bi, Transgender, we get everyone here, and everyone is
> > welcome, unless you're an asshole.
> >
> > One of my gay card references got a couple of customers laughing who
> > said "OMG, we should TOTALLY make GAY CARDS for people to carry
> > around!!!"  If anyone does though it should list their hanky code on it.
> >
> > I hear Nigger/Nigga (see, made you gasp!) at least 20x a shift.  It's
> > always used funny or as an endearment, and yes, by the black guys I work
> > with.  A few weeks ago an asshole called the guy on door that and
> > threatened to kill him for not letting him back in after getting kicked
> > out.  Yelled it out his car window driving by (real brave). We could
> > have gotten aggro but instead I looked at JB and said "Holy shit....
> > you're black??"  "On radio "Hey guys!!  Did you know the JB was black?"
> > JB retorted "I am as shocked as the rest of you to find this out."
> >
> > Then again, I'll flare up like pack of hemorrhoids with hate speech
> > anywhere near the club.  It's inappropriate and uncalled for.  People
> > slinging it at another to cause hurt have no business being there.  They
> > are ejected with extreme prejudice.
> >
> > The irony with ALL of the hateful words, is not one single one is
> > considered bad form, or even offensive to say about white people.  Not
> > starting an argument or debate on this, just pointing this out as a
> > "Hmmmm......"
> >
> > --S
> >
> > dangrsmind@yahoo.com wrote:
> > > You know, Alex, it is a choice to use words that offend people.  You
> can
> > chose not to use these words.
> > >
> > > However, it is also a choice to be offended by a word that someone else
> > uses. One can also choose not to be offended.
> > >
> > > One of things about the gay community I've always respected was the way
> > > they appropriated the pink triangle for themselves. The pink triangle
> was
> > used by the Nazis (Godwin Alert)  to
> > > identify homosexuals for incarcerations and subsequent elimination.
> > > In spite of this, the gay community has taken this symbol for
> > > themselves; some might know about the giant triangle that is displayed
> > > during pride week.  Can you imagine the Jewish community self
> > > identifying with the Nazi's yellow star?  I can't.
> > >
> > > I served on a jury a few months back, and I remember the defense
> > > attorneys taking the time to explain the difference between the n-word
> > > ending in -er and ending in -ah.  Only it was bullshit.  They are the
> > > same exact word, the difference seems to be that the word is used by
> > > different people in different contexts.
> > >
> > > Most of my gay friends self identify with the f-word.  My good friend
> > > Jesse actually calls hims self an "old f-word" most frequently,
> > > although sometimes he uses the q-word as well.  He would probably laugh
> > > at a gay person who was offended I think.  And of course Shatter
> pointed
> > out the well known Friday night parties that graced the End Up for many
> many
> > years. I don't recall anyone protesting or complaining, but maybe someone
> > did.
> > >
> > > I know a lot of us including myself are grateful to Apollo for all of
> the
> > wisdom he's shared over the years, the parties hes thrown, and so on.
>  He's
> > an inspiration to many of us on this list.  Apollo I don't agreee with
> you
> > at all on this issue, but I wish you hte best and thank you for
> everything
> > you've given of yourself.  I understand your decision and you will be
> sorely
> > missed.
> > >
> > > In my biew, we shouldn't let any word control us, and if you are
> offended
> > by the n-word, the f-word , the-c-word, or any other word you are
> allowing
> > yourself to be controlled by the people that use those words.  Take back
> the
> > words and you are free.
> > >
> > > Think about it.
> > >
> > > Best,
> > >
> > > Peter
> > >
> > >

>> On Mon, Nov 10, 2008 at 4:13 PM, Nyc Labrets <digitalcomponents@gmail.com>wrote:
>>
>>     
>>> We live in a country where instead of celebrating that a 40+ year old woman
>>> looking good enough to show off her healthy body, we lose our shit on a
>>> national level when Janet Jackson nearly flashes a tit on live TV.
>>>
>>> And it's been years since George Carlin first did his 7 dirty words bit,
>>> and
>>> he up and died before that one got changed, as a matter of fact the US
>>> Supreme Court said you can't do that, still:
>>> http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/F.C.C._v._Pacifica_Foundation
>>>
>>> Doubt that that's gonna get overturned anytime soon.
>>>
>>> Unless of course, you're Joe Scarborough
>>> http://wonkette.com/404267/joe-scarborough-says-f-word-on-live-television
>>>
>>>
>>> There's a an art to using shock words for effect which is lost on FM radio
>>> morning zoo types.
>>>
>>> The other night some Neo Nazi skinhead I was talking with at a party I was
>>> at, on the 70th Anniversary of Kristal Nacht, no less, called Obama the N
>>> word, and I shot back, in German, with,
>>>
>>> 'Yeah, he's a n****r alright, that's true, but at least, unlike your Herr
>>> Hitller, at least he's a WINNER and not a whilte skinned LOSER that had to
>>> shoot his White brains out, right?'
>>>
>>> Fucking idiot was so pissed, and speechless, that the only thing he and his
>>> friends could do was throw down on me, (you should have seen their eyes do
>>> pinwheels, in real life it looks just the same as it does in cartooons),
>>> they but I just laughed at them and wished them a good evening as I walked
>>> off.
>>>
>>> But anywayz America at its core is a Puritan country, (with the emotional
>>> maturity of a 15 year old, which is why fart\dick jokes are big here and
>>> Adam Sandler still gets $20 million a picture), and it's never going to
>>> change, and the battle of words you're engaged in is prolly a losing one,
>>> but feel free to try.
>>>
>>> Sign me your loyal and faithful translucent honky ass cracker trailer trash
>>> motherfucker.
>>>
>>> ....

>>> On Mon, Nov 10, 2008 at 8:41 AM, Shatter <shatter@sonic.net> wrote:
>>>
>>>       
>>>> PORCH MONKEY 4 LIFE!
>>>>
>>>> I'm taking it back!
>>>>
>>>> (if you haven't seen Clerks 2, please don't be offended)
>>>>
>>>> -----------------------------
>>>>
>>>> I have a soft spot for offensive words.  I don't feel ANY word should be
>>>> verbotten.  There is a proper time and place for all words.  The more
>>>> offensive, the better, because there are times it's the only thing to
>>>> shock people out of their stupor.  Over use can diminish the word
>>>> though.  South park did a fine example of this with Night of 1000
>>>> Shits.  By #120 you sorta don't even notice or care anymore, but teh
>>>> first 10-15 were funny as hell.  Hateful words can be turned around to
>>>> show how utterly stupid peopel are for using them.  I mean, common, far
>>>> better ways to insult somebody other than genetics.  Linage is a far
>>>> better one...  ;)
>>>>
>>>> At Endup with Fag Fridays there were MANY times I got to use the club
>>>> name in some creative uses.  Everyone one of the times it was directed
>>>> at uptight straight people who were shocked on everyones behalf,
>>>> typically to the laughter of the crowd hanging around.  Typically
>>>> something along the lines of "Well, it's call FAG FRIDAY...  you tell me
>>>> if you think it's a Gay Club." At which point they would start in with
>>>> something like "DO I LOOK GAY?" (best question ever) to which i would
>>>> usually respond with any number of "Well I don't want to fuck you,l so I
>>>> don't really care if you are or not" or "I have no idea what GAY looks
>>>> like" or "I don't know, go in and dance with all the shirtless guys and
>>>> let me know how it works out for you....   unless you're HOMOPHOBIC"
>>>> Good times.  At one of the anniversaries a great moment of taking the
>>>> hate and making it endearment was David Harness on the mic say "Hello!
>>>> Any Fags in this party tonight?" and in response a unified cheering
>>>> applause with massive whoops and yells.
>>>>
>>>> On the other hand, I have turned away, and will always as long as I work
>>>> there continue to turn away anyone who for a split second suggests they
>>>> may have a problem with Gay/Black/Asian/White, etc.  I will not abide by
>>>> hate.  When asked these days if it's a Gay Club I say "It's an everybody
>>>> club.  I'm not checking peoples gay cards, just their legal ID.  Gay,
>>>> Straight, Bi, Transgender, we get everyone here, and everyone is
>>>> welcome, unless you're an asshole.
>>>>
>>>> One of my gay card references got a couple of customers laughing who
>>>> said "OMG, we should TOTALLY make GAY CARDS for people to carry
>>>> around!!!"  If anyone does though it should list their hanky code on it.
>>>>
>>>> I hear Nigger/Nigga (see, made you gasp!) at least 20x a shift.  It's
>>>> always used funny or as an endearment, and yes, by the black guys I work
>>>> with.  A few weeks ago an asshole called the guy on door that and
>>>> threatened to kill him for not letting him back in after getting kicked
>>>> out.  Yelled it out his car window driving by (real brave). We could
>>>> have gotten aggro but instead I looked at JB and said "Holy shit....
>>>> you're black??"  "On radio "Hey guys!!  Did you know the JB was black?"
>>>> JB retorted "I am as shocked as the rest of you to find this out."
>>>>
>>>> Then again, I'll flare up like pack of hemorrhoids with hate speech
>>>> anywhere near the club.  It's inappropriate and uncalled for.  People
>>>> slinging it at another to cause hurt have no business being there.  They
>>>> are ejected with extreme prejudice.
>>>>
>>>> The irony with ALL of the hateful words, is not one single one is
>>>> considered bad form, or even offensive to say about white people.  Not
>>>> starting an argument or debate on this, just pointing this out as a
>>>> "Hmmmm......"
>>>>
>>>> --S
>>>>
>>>> dangrsmind@yahoo.com wrote:
>>>>         
>>>>> You know, Alex, it is a choice to use words that offend people.  You
>>>>>           
>>> can
>>>       
>>>> chose not to use these words.
>>>>         
>>>>> However, it is also a choice to be offended by a word that someone else
>>>>>           
>>>> uses. One can also choose not to be offended.
>>>>         
>>>>> One of things about the gay community I've always respected was the way
>>>>> they appropriated the pink triangle for themselves. The pink triangle
>>>>>           
>>> was
>>>       
>>>> used by the Nazis (Godwin Alert)  to
>>>>         
>>>>> identify homosexuals for incarcerations and subsequent elimination.
>>>>> In spite of this, the gay community has taken this symbol for
>>>>> themselves; some might know about the giant triangle that is displayed
>>>>> during pride week.  Can you imagine the Jewish community self
>>>>> identifying with the Nazi's yellow star?  I can't.
>>>>>
>>>>> I served on a jury a few months back, and I remember the defense
>>>>> attorneys taking the time to explain the difference between the n-word
>>>>> ending in -er and ending in -ah.  Only it was bullshit.  They are the
>>>>> same exact word, the difference seems to be that the word is used by
>>>>> different people in different contexts.
>>>>>
>>>>> Most of my gay friends self identify with the f-word.  My good friend
>>>>> Jesse actually calls hims self an "old f-word" most frequently,
>>>>> although sometimes he uses the q-word as well.  He would probably laugh
>>>>> at a gay person who was offended I think.  And of course Shatter
>>>>>           
>>> pointed
>>>       
>>>> out the well known Friday night parties that graced the End Up for many
>>>>         
>>> many
>>>       
>>>> years. I don't recall anyone protesting or complaining, but maybe someone
>>>> did.
>>>>         
>>>>> I know a lot of us including myself are grateful to Apollo for all of
>>>>>           
>>> the
>>>       
>>>> wisdom he's shared over the years, the parties hes thrown, and so on.
>>>>         
>>>  He's
>>>       
>>>> an inspiration to many of us on this list.  Apollo I don't agreee with
>>>>         
>>> you
>>>       
>>>> at all on this issue, but I wish you hte best and thank you for
>>>>         
>>> everything
>>>       
>>>> you've given of yourself.  I understand your decision and you will be
>>>>         
>>> sorely
>>>       
>>>> missed.
>>>>         
>>>>> In my biew, we shouldn't let any word control us, and if you are
>>>>>           
>>> offended
>>>       
>>>> by the n-word, the f-word , the-c-word, or any other word you are
>>>>         
>>> allowing
>>>       
>>>> yourself to be controlled by the people that use those words.  Take back
>>>>         
>>> the
>>>       
>>>> words and you are free.
>>>>         
>>>>> Think about it.
>>>>>
>>>>> Best,
>>>>>
>>>>> Peter

Subject: [sfraves] SRR: The Volstead Act

"By the turn of the 20th century, temperance societies were prevalent in
the United States. Concerned citizens had begun warning others about
the effects of alcohol nearly 100 years earlier. In 1826 the American
Temperance Society was founded to convince people to abstain from
drinking. Not long after, the Women's Christian Temperance Union
pledged not only to ban alcohol and drugs, but to improve public
morals. The anti-Saloon League was formed in 1893 and eventually became
a powerful political force in passing a national ban on alcoholic
beverages."

http://www.archives.gov/education/lessons/volstead-act/

MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Message-ID: <172962.63983.qm@web32401.mail.mud.yahoo.com>
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] SRR: Moonshining and Prohibition

Long before the 18th Amendment outlawed the sale and consumption of alcohol in America, prohibition and moonshine had already formed an uneasy relationship. 


Starting in the late 1870's the prohibition or temperance movements began to slowly  seep into the South, town by town or county by county. By the 1890's the movement  was gaining strength nationally, a fact that aided moonshiners tremendously. If a town  outlawed the legal sale of liquor, the demand for moonshiners and their product became  even greater. Prohibition reached much of the South on a state-wide level in the early twentieth  century. 


Prohibition also helped lower the standards of many moonshiners, the emphasis became  quantity of liquor that could be produced with the quality taking a backseat. Faced  with little alternative, thirsty drinkers were often not very discriminating and accepted "mean whiskey". 
http://www.ibiblio.org/moonshine/sell/prohibition.html

not here much but i lurk, you know, and it became like a comfort to see 
Apollo's posts ... it's rare in my experience to find people who actually 
care about more than themselves, who stand for something good and who add 
value to a discussion with their intelligence and compassion, even if you 
don't always agree ...

i hope maybe you'll just take a break and decide to come back, Apollo!

i'll be missing you!  :(

respectfully from the other coast,
mary :)
 
----- Original Message ----
From: Apollo <djapollo2k@mac.com>
To: SFRaves@hyperreal.org
Sent: Sunday, November 9, 2008 1:22:01 PM
Subject: [sfraves] Goodbye

You know, folks, I've been on this list off and on (mainly on) since the 
beginning.  This last run has lasted about ten years and I'm thinking 
that's enough.  Most of my close friends are gone from the list and of 
those that remain, well, I can keep in contact with them on other more 
pleasant venues.

Much love,

Apollo


--=_alternative 007D5BE5852574FE_=--

Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR: urban exploring?

We used to go down into the steam tunnels back in the day.   http://www.ocf.berkeley.edu/~fricke/undercal/

But then we also used have a party every summer in the Chancellor's house backyard when he wasn't there.  Hawaiian theme because there is a nice palm tree back there.

These days I am pretty sure they'll cal SWAT if do any of the shit we used to do.

In SF, its mostly mythology: http://xpress.sfsu.edu/archives/magazine/005793.html

Some friends do urban kayaking in the canals down in Foster City and there are some tunnels/pipes for the daring...

Peter

Delivered-To: mailing list sfraves@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 13813 invoked from network); 12 Nov 2008 18:21:22 -0000
X-YMail-OSG: 26.p8agVM1n6pzXxwNnoeOdLB8cbiI1itIaPU9epb6l.vya1tYsiWhW9KV_._I7z1ppodNQP1c4KP7jbt7M2ICM.N9omSC1fucD85FvQFBGNBiV.TiWj7.XYG7BSNEyvLNU-

Mime-Version: 1.0 (Apple Message framework v753.1)
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Message-Id: <705920A8-B88E-494C-AB8E-FBC1652337E3@deepfog.com>
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII; delsp=yes; format=flowed
To: "The Twilight Laser Outpost (West)" <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
From: Deepfog <sfo@deepfog.com>
Date: Wed, 12 Nov 2008 10:21:26 -0800
X-Mailer: Apple Mail (2.753.1)
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] (nrr) QOD (Wed)

The phone rang.  Marcus picked up the phone.

"You ready?"

"Just gotta grab my jacket," he said to Deepfog.

"Wait," said Pinkko.  "Someone just posted something, I have to  
reply."  By this time, Deepfog was already in the house.  "He always  
does this."  They both turned and walked to the door.  "I'll meet you  
out there."

"That's what you said the last time when we missed the Harmony 50  
year," said Chuck.  "We need to stop at Jack-In-The-Box on the way."

"Would you stop shape shifting?  Either decide you are Chuck or  
Marcus, I can't handle this indecisiveness."

In the car, Deepfog brought up SFRaves on the GPS device, 15 new  
messages from Pinkko.  "Well, we're gonna stop at Transit before we  
hit the Ambient Mafia 43rd anniversary."

"What?  That's in DC.  You're smoking crack."  With a strange sound,  
Marcus and Chuck shape-shifted into two different people.  "Let's get  
some curly fries."

"Hang on."  Deepfog whipped a quick left and up a ramp.  The car came  
to a quick halt and the magnetic wheel braces clicked on.  He got out  
of the 2008 Yugo Barack Obama edition that was given to every  
American citizen back then.

They all got out and entered the cockpit.  The computer lit up and  
spoke, "please enter your destination."

Deepfog looked at Marcus.  "Transit."  Deepfog looked at Chuck.   
"Sorry, they don't have Jack-in-the-Box in Virginia."

With a swirling poof, they went from I-880 to I-495 as quickly as if  
there were an interchange between the two.

to be continued ...

For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

I would really like all of you who want to come to
Prohibition to be able to get in, so please please
please buy presales if you intend on coming.

looking like we may sell out and have to turn people

200 presales have been purchased so far.  I have a
feeling a number of friends who say they're coming
just haven't bought presales, which could end up bad
at the door.

Subject: [sfraves] (nrr) QOD (Thu)

Now when we post to SFR, we can have a self-regulating guideline.   
Would your grandma approve?

We played around with Javascript this week and found a nice, stern  
grandmother picture.  Click on each of her eyes for messages of  
guidance on what to post.  Click on the neck of steel.  Then click on  
her ear to ask a question and see what she says.

In other news, this Saturday sees the tides going from 7 feet down to  
-1.5.  A good time to get shacked?

we resume ...

-

A not so loud alarm sounded and a red proximity alert sounded.

"What's that?"  said Chuck, with a plate of potato medallions.

"You might not want to eat that, I think Nat the burger guy is  
working at Transit tonight."  Deepfog reached over, hit the alarm,  
and pressed the greyed out button that said 'cloak & evade'.  "We've  
been detected .. possibly by NORAD but it's really not that big of a  
deal."

This little spacecraft, Renegade II, was really kind of a can with a  
car in it.  A bulletproof can, but still a can.  It fit the Yugo, had  
a small armory, and could certainly fit a sizeable grocery run, but  
not much else.  So they were able to land in the bushes behind  
Transit and switched to stealth mode, which is not quite as good as  
the full cloak, but gives off less radiation.  Hey, it's good if you  
don't want to end up sterile your whole life.

As they turned the corner, they noticed there was a crowd outside and  
quite a commotion.  No cop cars, but quite a commotion.  No violence,  
just quite a commotion.  All of the regular DCRaves celebrities came  
into focus.  Osby, who had just hitchiked across the country, came  
running toward them.

"Geri Dahl has been kidnapped!"

oh, shucks!  to be continued ...

Subject: [sfraves] BSP: Bassic Instinct @ Mozaic's Mixtape Party 2nite @ Shine

------=_Part_33612_1980581.1226611909009
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=ISO-8859-1
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Content-Disposition: inline

Bassic Instinct will be flying into shine on their ROFLcopter to drop an ill
dj set featuring their yet to be released studio projects and other
skullduggery.  Ranging from tech house to techno to electro, this shit
knocks.  Their track Thundercats, which has been featured on an XLR8R
Podcast and is getting heavy plays in the Bay Area and across the globe, is
slated for the first release on the forthcoming Rock It Science Laboratories
label with remixes by NYC's DJ Fame (Dubsided, Potty Mouth), Amsterdam's
Sick Boy (Crux Records), and SF's Homero Espinosa (Yerba Buena Discos,
Control).

*Info on Bassic Instinct *( http://www.myspace.com/bassicinstinctsf )

Emerging from the twisted musical minds of Bass Cadet (formerly known as
Friction) and Eric Sharp, Bassic Instinct tracks are tough, slamming peak
hour dance floor demolition material generally spanning a spectrum of
techno, tech house, and electro. Already getting loads of dancefloor support
before their first release, watch for Bassic Instinct to make a serious mark
at a raging party near you!

*Info on Mixtape:

*So with holidaze falling on the 4th Thursday in Nov and Dec, Mixtape's
getting moved to 2nd Thursdays for a couple of months....

This month's guests:

TIMONKEY (Muti Music) - live

BASSIC INSTINCT
[ERIC SHARP & BASS CADET aka FRICTION]

MIHKAL (Connoisseur Collective)


@ Shine
1337 Mission (at 9th)
10pm-2am
$5


See you there ;)

ic101.htm=0A>>>>=0A>>>>>=0A>>>>>> The US is:=A0 "...a nation of 200 million=

he=0A>>>>=0A>>>>> world who tries to make us uncomfortable."=0A>>>>>> -Hunt=

Subject: [sfraves] BSP: Bassic Instinct @ Mozaic's Mixtape Party 2nite @ Shine

------=_Part_33612_1980581.1226611909009
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=ISO-8859-1
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Content-Disposition: inline

Bassic Instinct will be flying into shine on their ROFLcopter to drop an ill
dj set featuring their yet to be released studio projects and other
skullduggery.  Ranging from tech house to techno to electro, this shit
knocks.  Their track Thundercats, which has been featured on an XLR8R
Podcast and is getting heavy plays in the Bay Area and across the globe, is
slated for the first release on the forthcoming Rock It Science Laboratories
label with remixes by NYC's DJ Fame (Dubsided, Potty Mouth), Amsterdam's
Sick Boy (Crux Records), and SF's Homero Espinosa (Yerba Buena Discos,
Control).

*Info on Bassic Instinct *( http://www.myspace.com/bassicinstinctsf )

Emerging from the twisted musical minds of Bass Cadet (formerly known as
Friction) and Eric Sharp, Bassic Instinct tracks are tough, slamming peak
hour dance floor demolition material generally spanning a spectrum of
techno, tech house, and electro. Already getting loads of dancefloor support
before their first release, watch for Bassic Instinct to make a serious mark
at a raging party near you!

*Info on Mixtape:

*So with holidaze falling on the 4th Thursday in Nov and Dec, Mixtape's
getting moved to 2nd Thursdays for a couple of months....

This month's guests:

TIMONKEY (Muti Music) - live

BASSIC INSTINCT
[ERIC SHARP & BASS CADET aka FRICTION]

MIHKAL (Connoisseur Collective)


@ Shine
1337 Mission (at 9th)
10pm-2am
$5


See you there ;)

Subject: [sfraves] BSP: Bassic Instinct @ Mozaic's Mixtape Party 2nite @ Shine

------=_Part_33612_1980581.1226611909009
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=ISO-8859-1
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Content-Disposition: inline

Bassic Instinct will be flying into shine on their ROFLcopter to drop an ill
dj set featuring their yet to be released studio projects and other
skullduggery.  Ranging from tech house to techno to electro, this shit
knocks.  Their track Thundercats, which has been featured on an XLR8R
Podcast and is getting heavy plays in the Bay Area and across the globe, is
slated for the first release on the forthcoming Rock It Science Laboratories
label with remixes by NYC's DJ Fame (Dubsided, Potty Mouth), Amsterdam's
Sick Boy (Crux Records), and SF's Homero Espinosa (Yerba Buena Discos,
Control).

*Info on Bassic Instinct *( http://www.myspace.com/bassicinstinctsf )

Emerging from the twisted musical minds of Bass Cadet (formerly known as
Friction) and Eric Sharp, Bassic Instinct tracks are tough, slamming peak
hour dance floor demolition material generally spanning a spectrum of
techno, tech house, and electro. Already getting loads of dancefloor support
before their first release, watch for Bassic Instinct to make a serious mark
at a raging party near you!

*Info on Mixtape:

*So with holidaze falling on the 4th Thursday in Nov and Dec, Mixtape's
getting moved to 2nd Thursdays for a couple of months....

This month's guests:

TIMONKEY (Muti Music) - live

BASSIC INSTINCT
[ERIC SHARP & BASS CADET aka FRICTION]

MIHKAL (Connoisseur Collective)


@ Shine
1337 Mission (at 9th)
10pm-2am
$5


See you there ;)

------=_Part_33612_1980581.1226611909009--

> > hour dance floor demolition material generally spanning a spectrum of
> > techno, tech house, and electro. Already getting loads of dancefloor
> support
> > before their first release, watch for Bassic Instinct to make a serious
> mark

*[Snoop]*
Still Snoop Dogg and D-R-E (Guess who's back)
Still, still doing that shit, right?

*[Dr. Dre]*
Oh for sure, check me out
It's still Dre Day, A.K.
Before I chrome the lot, can't keep it home a lot
'cause when I frequent the spots that I'm known to rock
You hear the bass from the trunk when I'm on the block
Ladies, they pay homage, but haters say Dre fell off
How? My last album was "The Chronic"
They want to know if he still got it
They say rap's changed, they want to know how I feel about it

*[Snoop - singing]*
If you ain't up on pace

*[Dr. Dre]*
Dr. Dre is the name, I'm ahead of my game
Still, puffing my leafs, still with the beats
Still not loving police (Uh huh)
Still rock my khakis with a cuff and a crease
Still got love for the streets, repping 213
Still the beat bangs, still doing my thang
Since I left, ain't too much changed, still

*[Chorus:]*
*[Snoop Dogg]*
I'm representing for them gangsters all across the world
Still hitting them corners in them low low's girl
*[Dr. Dre]*
Still taking my time to perfect the beat
And I still got love for the streets, it's the D-R-E *[Repeat 2x]*

Since the last time you heard from me I lost some friends
Well, hell, me and Snoop, we dipping again
Kept my ear to the streets, signed Eminem
He's triple platinum, doing 50 a week
Still, I stay close to the heat
And even when I was close to defeat, I rose to my feet
My life is like a soundtrack I wrote to the beat
Treat my rap like Cali weed, I smoke till I sleep
Wake up in the A.M., compose a beat
I bring the fire till you're soaking in your seat
It's not a fluke, it's been tried, I'm the troop
It's "Turn Out the Lights" from the World Class Wreckin' Cru
I'm still at it, After-mathematic
In the home of drivebys and ak-matics
Swap meets, sticky green, and bad traffic
I dip through then I get skin, D-R-E

*[Chorus]*

It ain't nothing but more hot shit
Another classic CD for y'all to vibe with
Whether you're cooling on a corner with your fly bitch
Laid back in the shack, play this track
I'm representing for the gangsters all across the world
(Still hitting them corners in them low low's girl)
I'll break your neck, damn near put your face in your lap
Try to be the king but the ace is back

*[Snoop - singing]*
So if you ain't up on thangs

*[Dr. Dre]*
Dr. Dre be the name still running the game
Still got it wrapped like a mummy
Still ain't tripping, love to see young blacks get money
Spend time out the hood, take they moms out the hood
Hit my boys off with jobs, no more living hard
Barbeques every day, driving fancy cars
Still gonna' get mine regardless

*[Chorus x1.5]*

*[Snoop]*
Like that, right back up in ya
'95 plus four pennies
Add that shit up, D-R-E right back on top of thangs
Smoke some with your dog
No stress, no seeds, no stems, no sticks!
Some of that real sticky icky
A little weed, put it in the air
For you's a fool D.R.
